Coverage for /home/balter/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sympy/solvers/ode.py : 4%

3576 statements   145 run 3431 missing 0 excluded

Hot-keys on this page

r m x p   toggle line displays

j k   next/prev highlighted chunk

0   (zero) top of page

1   (one) first highlighted chunk

1r""" 

2This module contains :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` and different helper 

3functions that it uses. 

4 

5:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` solves ordinary differential equations. 

6See the docstring on the various functions for their uses. Note that partial 

7differential equations support is in ``pde.py``. Note that hint functions 

8have docstrings describing their various methods, but they are intended for 

9internal use. Use ``dsolve(ode, func, hint=hint)`` to solve an ODE using a 

10specific hint. See also the docstring on 

11:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`. 

12 

13**Functions in this module** 

14 

15 These are the user functions in this module: 

16 

17 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` - Solves ODEs. 

18 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` - Classifies ODEs into 

19 possible hints for :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`. 

20 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.checkodesol` - Checks if an equation is the 

21 solution to an ODE. 

22 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.homogeneous_order` - Returns the 

23 homogeneous order of an expression. 

24 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.infinitesimals` - Returns the infinitesimals 

25 of the Lie group of point transformations of an ODE, such that it is 

26 invariant. 

27 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode_checkinfsol` - Checks if the given infinitesimals 

28 are the actual infinitesimals of a first order ODE. 

29 

30 These are the non-solver helper functions that are for internal use. The 

31 user should use the various options to 

32 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` to obtain the functionality provided 

33 by these functions: 

34 

35 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.odesimp` - Does all forms of ODE 

36 simplification. 

37 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_sol_simplicity` - A key function for 

38 comparing solutions by simplicity. 

39 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.constantsimp` - Simplifies arbitrary 

40 constants. 

41 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.constant_renumber` - Renumber arbitrary 

42 constants. 

43 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode._handle_Integral` - Evaluate unevaluated 

44 Integrals. 

45 

46 See also the docstrings of these functions. 

47 

48**Currently implemented solver methods** 

49 

50The following methods are implemented for solving ordinary differential 

51equations. See the docstrings of the various hint functions for more 

52information on each (run ``help(ode)``): 

53 

54 - 1st order separable differential equations. 

55 - 1st order differential equations whose coefficients or `dx` and `dy` are 

56 functions homogeneous of the same order. 

57 - 1st order exact differential equations. 

58 - 1st order linear differential equations. 

59 - 1st order Bernoulli differential equations. 

60 - Power series solutions for first order differential equations. 

61 - Lie Group method of solving first order differential equations. 

62 - 2nd order Liouville differential equations. 

63 - Power series solutions for second order differential equations 

64 at ordinary and regular singular points. 

65 - `n`\th order differential equation that can be solved with algebraic 

66 rearrangement and integration. 

67 - `n`\th order linear homogeneous differential equation with constant 

68 coefficients. 

69 - `n`\th order linear inhomogeneous differential equation with constant 

70 coefficients using the method of undetermined coefficients. 

71 - `n`\th order linear inhomogeneous differential equation with constant 

72 coefficients using the method of variation of parameters. 

73 

74**Philosophy behind this module** 

75 

76This module is designed to make it easy to add new ODE solving methods without 

77having to mess with the solving code for other methods. The idea is that 

78there is a :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` function, which takes in 

79an ODE and tells you what hints, if any, will solve the ODE. It does this 

80without attempting to solve the ODE, so it is fast. Each solving method is a 

81hint, and it has its own function, named ``ode_<hint>``. That function takes 

82in the ODE and any match expression gathered by 

83:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` and returns a solved result. If 

84this result has any integrals in it, the hint function will return an 

85unevaluated :py:class:`~sympy.integrals.Integral` class. 

86:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`, which is the user wrapper function 

87around all of this, will then call :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.odesimp` on 

88the result, which, among other things, will attempt to solve the equation for 

89the dependent variable (the function we are solving for), simplify the 

90arbitrary constants in the expression, and evaluate any integrals, if the hint 

91allows it. 

92 

93**How to add new solution methods** 

94 

95If you have an ODE that you want :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` to be 

96able to solve, try to avoid adding special case code here. Instead, try 

97finding a general method that will solve your ODE, as well as others. This 

98way, the :py:mod:`~sympy.solvers.ode` module will become more robust, and 

99unhindered by special case hacks. WolphramAlpha and Maple's 

100DETools[odeadvisor] function are two resources you can use to classify a 

101specific ODE. It is also better for a method to work with an `n`\th order ODE 

102instead of only with specific orders, if possible. 

103 

104To add a new method, there are a few things that you need to do. First, you 

105need a hint name for your method. Try to name your hint so that it is 

106unambiguous with all other methods, including ones that may not be implemented 

107yet. If your method uses integrals, also include a ``hint_Integral`` hint. 

108If there is more than one way to solve ODEs with your method, include a hint 

109for each one, as well as a ``<hint>_best`` hint. Your ``ode_<hint>_best()`` 

110function should choose the best using min with ``ode_sol_simplicity`` as the 

111key argument. See 

112:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_best`, for example. 

113The function that uses your method will be called ``ode_<hint>()``, so the 

114hint must only use characters that are allowed in a Python function name 

115(alphanumeric characters and the underscore '``_``' character). Include a 

116function for every hint, except for ``_Integral`` hints 

117(:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` takes care of those automatically). 

118Hint names should be all lowercase, unless a word is commonly capitalized 

119(such as Integral or Bernoulli). If you have a hint that you do not want to 

120run with ``all_Integral`` that doesn't have an ``_Integral`` counterpart (such 

121as a best hint that would defeat the purpose of ``all_Integral``), you will 

122need to remove it manually in the :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` code. 

123See also the :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` docstring for 

124guidelines on writing a hint name. 

125 

126Determine *in general* how the solutions returned by your method compare with 

127other methods that can potentially solve the same ODEs. Then, put your hints 

128in the :py:data:`~sympy.solvers.ode.allhints` tuple in the order that they 

129should be called. The ordering of this tuple determines which hints are 

130default. Note that exceptions are ok, because it is easy for the user to 

131choose individual hints with :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`. In 

132general, ``_Integral`` variants should go at the end of the list, and 

133``_best`` variants should go before the various hints they apply to. For 

134example, the ``undetermined_coefficients`` hint comes before the 

135``variation_of_parameters`` hint because, even though variation of parameters 

136is more general than undetermined coefficients, undetermined coefficients 

137generally returns cleaner results for the ODEs that it can solve than 

138variation of parameters does, and it does not require integration, so it is 

139much faster. 

140 

141Next, you need to have a match expression or a function that matches the type 

142of the ODE, which you should put in :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` 

143(if the match function is more than just a few lines, like 

144:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode._undetermined_coefficients_match`, it should go 

145outside of :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode`). It should match the 

146ODE without solving for it as much as possible, so that 

147:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` remains fast and is not hindered by 

148bugs in solving code. Be sure to consider corner cases. For example, if your 

149solution method involves dividing by something, make sure you exclude the case 

150where that division will be 0. 

151 

152In most cases, the matching of the ODE will also give you the various parts 

153that you need to solve it. You should put that in a dictionary (``.match()`` 

154will do this for you), and add that as ``matching_hints['hint'] = matchdict`` 

155in the relevant part of :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode`. 

156:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` will then send this to 

157:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`, which will send it to your function as 

158the ``match`` argument. Your function should be named ``ode_<hint>(eq, func, 

159order, match)`. If you need to send more information, put it in the ``match`` 

160dictionary. For example, if you had to substitute in a dummy variable in 

161:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` to match the ODE, you will need to 

162pass it to your function using the `match` dict to access it. You can access 

163the independent variable using ``func.args[0]``, and the dependent variable 

164(the function you are trying to solve for) as ``func.func``. If, while trying 

165to solve the ODE, you find that you cannot, raise ``NotImplementedError``. 

166:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` will catch this error with the ``all`` 

167meta-hint, rather than causing the whole routine to fail. 

168 

169Add a docstring to your function that describes the method employed. Like 

170with anything else in SymPy, you will need to add a doctest to the docstring, 

171in addition to real tests in ``test_ode.py``. Try to maintain consistency 

172with the other hint functions' docstrings. Add your method to the list at the 

173top of this docstring. Also, add your method to ``ode.rst`` in the 

174``docs/src`` directory, so that the Sphinx docs will pull its docstring into 

175the main SymPy documentation. Be sure to make the Sphinx documentation by 

176running ``make html`` from within the doc directory to verify that the 

177docstring formats correctly. 

178 

179If your solution method involves integrating, use :py:meth:`Integral() 

180<sympy.integrals.integrals.Integral>` instead of 

181:py:meth:`~sympy.core.expr.Expr.integrate`. This allows the user to bypass 

182hard/slow integration by using the ``_Integral`` variant of your hint. In 

183most cases, calling :py:meth:`sympy.core.basic.Basic.doit` will integrate your 

184solution. If this is not the case, you will need to write special code in 

185:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode._handle_Integral`. Arbitrary constants should be 

186symbols named ``C1``, ``C2``, and so on. All solution methods should return 

187an equality instance. If you need an arbitrary number of arbitrary constants, 

188you can use ``constants = numbered_symbols(prefix='C', cls=Symbol, start=1)``. 

189If it is possible to solve for the dependent function in a general way, do so. 

190Otherwise, do as best as you can, but do not call solve in your 

191``ode_<hint>()`` function. :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.odesimp` will attempt 

192to solve the solution for you, so you do not need to do that. Lastly, if your 

193ODE has a common simplification that can be applied to your solutions, you can 

194add a special case in :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.odesimp` for it. For 

195example, solutions returned from the ``1st_homogeneous_coeff`` hints often 

196have many :py:meth:`~sympy.functions.log` terms, so 

197:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.odesimp` calls 

198:py:meth:`~sympy.simplify.simplify.logcombine` on them (it also helps to write 

199the arbitrary constant as ``log(C1)`` instead of ``C1`` in this case). Also 

200consider common ways that you can rearrange your solution to have 

201:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.constantsimp` take better advantage of it. It is 

202better to put simplification in :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.odesimp` than in 

203your method, because it can then be turned off with the simplify flag in 

204:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`. If you have any extraneous 

205simplification in your function, be sure to only run it using ``if 

206match.get('simplify', True):``, especially if it can be slow or if it can 

207reduce the domain of the solution. 

208 

209Finally, as with every contribution to SymPy, your method will need to be 

210tested. Add a test for each method in ``test_ode.py``. Follow the 

211conventions there, i.e., test the solver using ``dsolve(eq, f(x), 

212hint=your_hint)``, and also test the solution using 

213:py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.checkodesol` (you can put these in a separate 

214tests and skip/XFAIL if it runs too slow/doesn't work). Be sure to call your 

215hint specifically in :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`, that way the test 

216won't be broken simply by the introduction of another matching hint. If your 

217method works for higher order (>1) ODEs, you will need to run ``sol = 

218constant_renumber(sol, 'C', 1, order)`` for each solution, where ``order`` is 

219the order of the ODE. This is because ``constant_renumber`` renumbers the 

220arbitrary constants by printing order, which is platform dependent. Try to 

221test every corner case of your solver, including a range of orders if it is a 

222`n`\th order solver, but if your solver is slow, such as if it involves hard 

223integration, try to keep the test run time down. 

224 

225Feel free to refactor existing hints to avoid duplicating code or creating 

226inconsistencies. If you can show that your method exactly duplicates an 

227existing method, including in the simplicity and speed of obtaining the 

228solutions, then you can remove the old, less general method. The existing 

229code is tested extensively in ``test_ode.py``, so if anything is broken, one 

230of those tests will surely fail. 

231 

232""" 

233from __future__ import print_function, division

249from sympy.core.symbol import Symbol, Wild, Dummy, symbols

273from sympy.solvers.deutils import _preprocess, ode_order, _desolve

275#: This is a list of hints in the order that they should be preferred by 

276#: :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode`. In general, hints earlier in the 

277#: list should produce simpler solutions than those later in the list (for 

278#: ODEs that fit both). For now, the order of this list is based on empirical 

279#: observations by the developers of SymPy. 

280#: 

281#: The hint used by :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` for a specific ODE 

282#: can be overridden (see the docstring). 

283#: 

284#: In general, ``_Integral`` hints are grouped at the end of the list, unless 

285#: there is a method that returns an unevaluable integral most of the time 

286#: (which go near the end of the list anyway). ``default``, ``all``, 

287#: ``best``, and ``all_Integral`` meta-hints should not be included in this 

288#: list, but ``_best`` and ``_Integral`` hints should be included. 

289allhints = ( 

290 "nth_algebraic", 

291 "separable", 

292 "1st_exact", 

293 "1st_linear", 

294 "Bernoulli", 

295 "Riccati_special_minus2", 

296 "1st_homogeneous_coeff_best", 

297 "1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep", 

298 "1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep", 

299 "almost_linear", 

300 "linear_coefficients", 

301 "separable_reduced", 

302 "1st_power_series", 

303 "lie_group", 

304 "nth_linear_constant_coeff_homogeneous", 

305 "nth_linear_euler_eq_homogeneous", 

306 "nth_linear_constant_coeff_undetermined_coefficients", 

307 "nth_linear_euler_eq_nonhomogeneous_undetermined_coefficients", 

308 "nth_linear_constant_coeff_variation_of_parameters", 

309 "nth_linear_euler_eq_nonhomogeneous_variation_of_parameters", 

310 "Liouville", 

311 "nth_order_reducible", 

312 "2nd_power_series_ordinary", 

313 "2nd_power_series_regular", 

314 "nth_algebraic_Integral", 

315 "separable_Integral", 

316 "1st_exact_Integral", 

317 "1st_linear_Integral", 

318 "Bernoulli_Integral", 

319 "1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep_Integral", 

320 "1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep_Integral", 

321 "almost_linear_Integral", 

322 "linear_coefficients_Integral", 

323 "separable_reduced_Integral", 

324 "nth_linear_constant_coeff_variation_of_parameters_Integral", 

325 "nth_linear_euler_eq_nonhomogeneous_variation_of_parameters_Integral", 

326 "Liouville_Integral", 

327 ) 

328 

329lie_heuristics = ( 

330 "abaco1_simple", 

331 "abaco1_product", 

332 "abaco2_similar", 

333 "abaco2_unique_unknown", 

334 "abaco2_unique_general", 

335 "linear", 

336 "function_sum", 

337 "bivariate", 

338 "chi" 

339 ) 

340 

341 

342def sub_func_doit(eq, func, new): 

343 r""" 

344 When replacing the func with something else, we usually want the 

345 derivative evaluated, so this function helps in making that happen. 

346 

347 Examples 

348 ======== 

349 

350 >>> from sympy import Derivative, symbols, Function 

351 >>> from sympy.solvers.ode import sub_func_doit 

352 >>> x, z = symbols('x, z') 

353 >>> y = Function('y') 

354 

355 >>> sub_func_doit(3*Derivative(y(x), x) - 1, y(x), x) 

356 2 

357 

358 >>> sub_func_doit(x*Derivative(y(x), x) - y(x)**2 + y(x), y(x), 

359 ... 1/(x*(z + 1/x))) 

360 x*(-1/(x**2*(z + 1/x)) + 1/(x**3*(z + 1/x)**2)) + 1/(x*(z + 1/x)) 

361 ...- 1/(x**2*(z + 1/x)**2) 

362 """ 

363 reps= {func: new} 

364 for d in eq.atoms(Derivative): 

365 if d.expr == func: 

366 reps[d] = new.diff(*d.variable_count) 

367 else: 

368 reps[d] = d.xreplace({func: new}).doit(deep=False) 

369 return eq.xreplace(reps) 

370 

371 

372def get_numbered_constants(eq, num=1, start=1, prefix='C'): 

373 """ 

374 Returns a list of constants that do not occur 

375 in eq already. 

376 """ 

377 

378 ncs = iter_numbered_constants(eq, start, prefix) 

379 Cs = [next(ncs) for i in range(num)] 

380 return (Cs[0] if num == 1 else tuple(Cs)) 

381 

382 

383def iter_numbered_constants(eq, start=1, prefix='C'): 

384 """ 

385 Returns an iterator of constants that do not occur 

386 in eq already. 

387 """ 

388 

389 if isinstance(eq, Expr): 

390 eq = [eq] 

391 elif not iterable(eq): 

392 raise ValueError("Expected Expr or iterable but got %s" % eq) 

393 

394 atom_set = set().union(*[i.free_symbols for i in eq]) 

395 func_set = set().union(*[i.atoms(Function) for i in eq]) 

396 if func_set: 

397 atom_set |= {Symbol(str(f.func)) for f in func_set} 

398 return numbered_symbols(start=start, prefix=prefix, exclude=atom_set) 

399 

400 

401def dsolve(eq, func=None, hint="default", simplify=True, 

402 ics= None, xi=None, eta=None, x0=0, n=6, **kwargs): 

403 r""" 

404 Solves any (supported) kind of ordinary differential equation and 

405 system of ordinary differential equations. 

406 

407 For single ordinary differential equation 

408 ========================================= 

409 

410 It is classified under this when number of equation in ``eq`` is one. 

411 **Usage** 

412 

413 ``dsolve(eq, f(x), hint)`` -> Solve ordinary differential equation 

414 ``eq`` for function ``f(x)``, using method ``hint``. 

415 

416 **Details** 

417 

418 ``eq`` can be any supported ordinary differential equation (see the 

419 :py:mod:`~sympy.solvers.ode` docstring for supported methods). 

420 This can either be an :py:class:`~sympy.core.relational.Equality`, 

421 or an expression, which is assumed to be equal to ``0``. 

422 

423 ``f(x)`` is a function of one variable whose derivatives in that 

424 variable make up the ordinary differential equation ``eq``. In 

425 many cases it is not necessary to provide this; it will be 

426 autodetected (and an error raised if it couldn't be detected). 

427 

428 ``hint`` is the solving method that you want dsolve to use. Use 

429 ``classify_ode(eq, f(x))`` to get all of the possible hints for an 

430 ODE. The default hint, ``default``, will use whatever hint is 

431 returned first by :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode`. See 

432 Hints below for more options that you can use for hint. 

433 

434 ``simplify`` enables simplification by 

435 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.odesimp`. See its docstring for more 

436 information. Turn this off, for example, to disable solving of 

437 solutions for ``func`` or simplification of arbitrary constants. 

438 It will still integrate with this hint. Note that the solution may 

439 contain more arbitrary constants than the order of the ODE with 

440 this option enabled. 

441 

442 ``xi`` and ``eta`` are the infinitesimal functions of an ordinary 

443 differential equation. They are the infinitesimals of the Lie group 

444 of point transformations for which the differential equation is 

445 invariant. The user can specify values for the infinitesimals. If 

446 nothing is specified, ``xi`` and ``eta`` are calculated using 

447 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.infinitesimals` with the help of various 

448 heuristics. 

449 

450 ``ics`` is the set of initial/boundary conditions for the differential equation. 

451 It should be given in the form of ``{f(x0): x1, f(x).diff(x).subs(x, x2): 

452 x3}`` and so on. For power series solutions, if no initial 

453 conditions are specified ``f(0)`` is assumed to be ``C0`` and the power 

454 series solution is calculated about 0. 

455 

456 ``x0`` is the point about which the power series solution of a differential 

457 equation is to be evaluated. 

458 

459 ``n`` gives the exponent of the dependent variable up to which the power series 

460 solution of a differential equation is to be evaluated. 

461 

462 **Hints** 

463 

464 Aside from the various solving methods, there are also some meta-hints 

465 that you can pass to :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`: 

466 

467 ``default``: 

468 This uses whatever hint is returned first by 

469 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode`. This is the 

470 default argument to :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`. 

471 

472 ``all``: 

473 To make :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` apply all 

474 relevant classification hints, use ``dsolve(ODE, func, 

475 hint="all")``. This will return a dictionary of 

476 ``hint:solution`` terms. If a hint causes dsolve to raise the 

477 ``NotImplementedError``, value of that hint's key will be the 

478 exception object raised. The dictionary will also include 

479 some special keys: 

480 

481 - ``order``: The order of the ODE. See also 

482 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.deutils.ode_order` in 

483 ``deutils.py``. 

484 - ``best``: The simplest hint; what would be returned by 

485 ``best`` below. 

486 - ``best_hint``: The hint that would produce the solution 

487 given by ``best``. If more than one hint produces the best 

488 solution, the first one in the tuple returned by 

489 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` is chosen. 

490 - ``default``: The solution that would be returned by default. 

491 This is the one produced by the hint that appears first in 

492 the tuple returned by 

493 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode`. 

494 

495 ``all_Integral``: 

496 This is the same as ``all``, except if a hint also has a 

497 corresponding ``_Integral`` hint, it only returns the 

498 ``_Integral`` hint. This is useful if ``all`` causes 

499 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` to hang because of a 

500 difficult or impossible integral. This meta-hint will also be 

501 much faster than ``all``, because 

502 :py:meth:`~sympy.core.expr.Expr.integrate` is an expensive 

503 routine. 

504 

505 ``best``: 

506 To have :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` try all methods 

507 and return the simplest one. This takes into account whether 

508 the solution is solvable in the function, whether it contains 

509 any Integral classes (i.e. unevaluatable integrals), and 

510 which one is the shortest in size. 

511 

512 See also the :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` docstring for 

513 more info on hints, and the :py:mod:`~sympy.solvers.ode` docstring for 

514 a list of all supported hints. 

515 

516 **Tips** 

517 

518 - You can declare the derivative of an unknown function this way: 

519 

520 >>> from sympy import Function, Derivative 

521 >>> from sympy.abc import x # x is the independent variable 

522 >>> f = Function("f")(x) # f is a function of x 

523 >>> # f_ will be the derivative of f with respect to x 

524 >>> f_ = Derivative(f, x) 

525 

526 - See ``test_ode.py`` for many tests, which serves also as a set of 

527 examples for how to use :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`. 

528 - :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` always returns an 

529 :py:class:`~sympy.core.relational.Equality` class (except for the 

530 case when the hint is ``all`` or ``all_Integral``). If possible, it 

531 solves the solution explicitly for the function being solved for. 

532 Otherwise, it returns an implicit solution. 

533 - Arbitrary constants are symbols named ``C1``, ``C2``, and so on. 

534 - Because all solutions should be mathematically equivalent, some 

535 hints may return the exact same result for an ODE. Often, though, 

536 two different hints will return the same solution formatted 

537 differently. The two should be equivalent. Also note that sometimes 

538 the values of the arbitrary constants in two different solutions may 

539 not be the same, because one constant may have "absorbed" other 

540 constants into it. 

541 - Do ``help(ode.ode_<hintname>)`` to get help more information on a 

542 specific hint, where ``<hintname>`` is the name of a hint without 

543 ``_Integral``. 

544 

545 For system of ordinary differential equations 

546 ============================================= 

547 

548 **Usage** 

549 ``dsolve(eq, func)`` -> Solve a system of ordinary differential 

550 equations ``eq`` for ``func`` being list of functions including 

551 `x(t)`, `y(t)`, `z(t)` where number of functions in the list depends 

552 upon the number of equations provided in ``eq``. 

553 

554 **Details** 

555 

556 ``eq`` can be any supported system of ordinary differential equations 

557 This can either be an :py:class:`~sympy.core.relational.Equality`, 

558 or an expression, which is assumed to be equal to ``0``. 

559 

560 ``func`` holds ``x(t)`` and ``y(t)`` being functions of one variable which 

561 together with some of their derivatives make up the system of ordinary 

562 differential equation ``eq``. It is not necessary to provide this; it 

563 will be autodetected (and an error raised if it couldn't be detected). 

564 

565 **Hints** 

566 

567 The hints are formed by parameters returned by classify_sysode, combining 

568 them give hints name used later for forming method name. 

569 

570 Examples 

571 ======== 

572 

573 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, Eq, Derivative, sin, cos, symbols 

574 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

575 >>> f = Function('f') 

576 >>> dsolve(Derivative(f(x), x, x) + 9*f(x), f(x)) 

577 Eq(f(x), C1*sin(3*x) + C2*cos(3*x)) 

578 

579 >>> eq = sin(x)*cos(f(x)) + cos(x)*sin(f(x))*f(x).diff(x) 

580 >>> dsolve(eq, hint='1st_exact') 

581 [Eq(f(x), -acos(C1/cos(x)) + 2*pi), Eq(f(x), acos(C1/cos(x)))] 

582 >>> dsolve(eq, hint='almost_linear') 

583 [Eq(f(x), -acos(C1/cos(x)) + 2*pi), Eq(f(x), acos(C1/cos(x)))] 

584 >>> t = symbols('t') 

585 >>> x, y = symbols('x, y', cls=Function) 

586 >>> eq = (Eq(Derivative(x(t),t), 12*t*x(t) + 8*y(t)), Eq(Derivative(y(t),t), 21*x(t) + 7*t*y(t))) 

587 >>> dsolve(eq) 

588 [Eq(x(t), C1*x0(t) + C2*x0(t)*Integral(8*exp(Integral(7*t, t))*exp(Integral(12*t, t))/x0(t)**2, t)), 

589 Eq(y(t), C1*y0(t) + C2*(y0(t)*Integral(8*exp(Integral(7*t, t))*exp(Integral(12*t, t))/x0(t)**2, t) + 

590 exp(Integral(7*t, t))*exp(Integral(12*t, t))/x0(t)))] 

591 >>> eq = (Eq(Derivative(x(t),t),x(t)*y(t)*sin(t)), Eq(Derivative(y(t),t),y(t)**2*sin(t))) 

592 >>> dsolve(eq) 

593 {Eq(x(t), -exp(C1)/(C2*exp(C1) - cos(t))), Eq(y(t), -1/(C1 - cos(t)))} 

594 """ 

595 if iterable(eq): 

596 match = classify_sysode(eq, func) 

597 eq = match['eq'] 

598 order = match['order'] 

599 func = match['func'] 

600 t = list(list(eq[0].atoms(Derivative))[0].atoms(Symbol))[0] 

601 

602 # keep highest order term coefficient positive 

603 for i in range(len(eq)): 

604 for func_ in func: 

605 if isinstance(func_, list): 

606 pass 

607 else: 

608 if eq[i].coeff(diff(func[i],t,ode_order(eq[i], func[i]))).is_negative: 

609 eq[i] = -eq[i] 

610 match['eq'] = eq 

611 if len(set(order.values()))!=1: 

612 raise ValueError("It solves only those systems of equations whose orders are equal") 

613 match['order'] = list(order.values())[0] 

614 def recur_len(l): 

615 return sum(recur_len(item) if isinstance(item,list) else 1 for item in l) 

616 if recur_len(func) != len(eq): 

617 raise ValueError("dsolve() and classify_sysode() work with " 

618 "number of functions being equal to number of equations") 

619 if match['type_of_equation'] is None: 

620 raise NotImplementedError 

621 else: 

622 if match['is_linear'] == True: 

623 if match['no_of_equation'] > 3: 

624 solvefunc = globals()['sysode_linear_neq_order%(order)s' % match] 

625 else: 

626 solvefunc = globals()['sysode_linear_%(no_of_equation)seq_order%(order)s' % match] 

627 else: 

628 solvefunc = globals()['sysode_nonlinear_%(no_of_equation)seq_order%(order)s' % match] 

629 sols = solvefunc(match) 

630 if ics: 

631 constants = Tuple(*sols).free_symbols - Tuple(*eq).free_symbols 

632 solved_constants = solve_ics(sols, func, constants, ics) 

633 return [sol.subs(solved_constants) for sol in sols] 

634 return sols 

635 else: 

636 given_hint = hint # hint given by the user 

637 

638 # See the docstring of _desolve for more details. 

639 hints = _desolve(eq, func=func, 

640 hint=hint, simplify=True, xi=xi, eta=eta, type='ode', ics=ics, 

641 x0=x0, n=n, **kwargs) 

642 

643 eq = hints.pop('eq', eq) 

644 all_ = hints.pop('all', False) 

645 if all_: 

646 retdict = {} 

647 failed_hints = {} 

648 gethints = classify_ode(eq, dict=True) 

649 orderedhints = gethints['ordered_hints'] 

650 for hint in hints: 

651 try: 

652 rv = _helper_simplify(eq, hint, hints[hint], simplify) 

653 except NotImplementedError as detail: 

654 failed_hints[hint] = detail 

655 else: 

656 retdict[hint] = rv 

657 func = hints[hint]['func'] 

658 

659 retdict['best'] = min(list(retdict.values()), key=lambda x: 

660 ode_sol_simplicity(x, func, trysolving=not simplify)) 

661 if given_hint == 'best': 

662 return retdict['best'] 

663 for i in orderedhints: 

664 if retdict['best'] == retdict.get(i, None): 

665 retdict['best_hint'] = i 

666 break 

667 retdict['default'] = gethints['default'] 

668 retdict['order'] = gethints['order'] 

669 retdict.update(failed_hints) 

670 return retdict 

671 

672 else: 

673 # The key 'hint' stores the hint needed to be solved for. 

674 hint = hints['hint'] 

675 return _helper_simplify(eq, hint, hints, simplify, ics=ics) 

676 

677def _helper_simplify(eq, hint, match, simplify=True, ics=None, **kwargs): 

678 r""" 

679 Helper function of dsolve that calls the respective 

680 :py:mod:`~sympy.solvers.ode` functions to solve for the ordinary 

681 differential equations. This minimizes the computation in calling 

682 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.deutils._desolve` multiple times. 

683 """ 

684 r = match 

685 if hint.endswith('_Integral'): 

686 solvefunc = globals()['ode_' + hint[:-len('_Integral')]] 

687 else: 

688 solvefunc = globals()['ode_' + hint] 

689 func = r['func'] 

690 order = r['order'] 

691 match = r[hint] 

692 

693 free = eq.free_symbols 

694 cons = lambda s: s.free_symbols.difference(free) 

695 

696 if simplify: 

697 # odesimp() will attempt to integrate, if necessary, apply constantsimp(), 

698 # attempt to solve for func, and apply any other hint specific 

699 # simplifications 

700 sols = solvefunc(eq, func, order, match) 

701 if isinstance(sols, Expr): 

702 rv = odesimp(eq, sols, func, hint) 

703 else: 

704 rv = [odesimp(eq, s, func, hint) for s in sols] 

705 else: 

706 # We still want to integrate (you can disable it separately with the hint) 

707 match['simplify'] = False # Some hints can take advantage of this option 

708 rv = _handle_Integral(solvefunc(eq, func, order, match), func, hint) 

709 

710 if ics and not 'power_series' in hint: 

711 if isinstance(rv, Expr): 

712 solved_constants = solve_ics([rv], [r['func']], cons(rv), ics) 

713 rv = rv.subs(solved_constants) 

714 else: 

715 rv1 = [] 

716 for s in rv: 

717 try: 

718 solved_constants = solve_ics([s], [r['func']], cons(s), ics) 

719 except ValueError: 

720 continue 

721 rv1.append(s.subs(solved_constants)) 

722 if len(rv1) == 1: 

723 return rv1[0] 

724 rv = rv1 

725 return rv 

726 

727def solve_ics(sols, funcs, constants, ics): 

728 """ 

729 Solve for the constants given initial conditions 

730 

731 ``sols`` is a list of solutions. 

732 

733 ``funcs`` is a list of functions. 

734 

735 ``constants`` is a list of constants. 

736 

737 ``ics`` is the set of initial/boundary conditions for the differential 

738 equation. It should be given in the form of ``{f(x0): x1, 

739 f(x).diff(x).subs(x, x2): x3}`` and so on. 

740 

741 Returns a dictionary mapping constants to values. 

742 ``solution.subs(constants)`` will replace the constants in ``solution``. 

743 

744 Example 

745 ======= 

746 >>> # From dsolve(f(x).diff(x) - f(x), f(x)) 

747 >>> from sympy import symbols, Eq, exp, Function 

748 >>> from sympy.solvers.ode import solve_ics 

749 >>> f = Function('f') 

750 >>> x, C1 = symbols('x C1') 

751 >>> sols = [Eq(f(x), C1*exp(x))] 

752 >>> funcs = [f(x)] 

753 >>> constants = [C1] 

754 >>> ics = {f(0): 2} 

755 >>> solved_constants = solve_ics(sols, funcs, constants, ics) 

756 >>> solved_constants 

757 {C1: 2} 

758 >>> sols[0].subs(solved_constants) 

759 Eq(f(x), 2*exp(x)) 

760 

761 """ 

762 # Assume ics are of the form f(x0): value or Subs(diff(f(x), x, n), (x, 

763 # x0)): value (currently checked by classify_ode). To solve, replace x 

764 # with x0, f(x0) with value, then solve for constants. For f^(n)(x0), 

765 # differentiate the solution n times, so that f^(n)(x) appears. 

766 x = funcs[0].args[0] 

767 diff_sols = [] 

768 subs_sols = [] 

769 diff_variables = set() 

770 for funcarg, value in ics.items(): 

771 if isinstance(funcarg, AppliedUndef): 

772 x0 = funcarg.args[0] 

773 matching_func = [f for f in funcs if f.func == funcarg.func][0] 

774 S = sols 

775 elif isinstance(funcarg, (Subs, Derivative)): 

776 if isinstance(funcarg, Subs): 

777 # Make sure it stays a subs. Otherwise subs below will produce 

778 # a different looking term. 

779 funcarg = funcarg.doit() 

780 if isinstance(funcarg, Subs): 

781 deriv = funcarg.expr 

782 x0 = funcarg.point[0] 

783 variables = funcarg.expr.variables 

784 matching_func = deriv 

785 elif isinstance(funcarg, Derivative): 

786 deriv = funcarg 

787 x0 = funcarg.variables[0] 

788 variables = (x,)*len(funcarg.variables) 

789 matching_func = deriv.subs(x0, x) 

790 if variables not in diff_variables: 

791 for sol in sols: 

792 if sol.has(deriv.expr.func): 

793 diff_sols.append(Eq(sol.lhs.diff(*variables), sol.rhs.diff(*variables))) 

794 diff_variables.add(variables) 

795 S = diff_sols 

796 else: 

797 raise NotImplementedError("Unrecognized initial condition") 

798 

799 for sol in S: 

800 if sol.has(matching_func): 

801 sol2 = sol 

802 sol2 = sol2.subs(x, x0) 

803 sol2 = sol2.subs(funcarg, value) 

804 # This check is necessary because of issue #15724 

805 if not isinstance(sol2, BooleanAtom) or not subs_sols: 

806 subs_sols = [s for s in subs_sols if not isinstance(s, BooleanAtom)] 

807 subs_sols.append(sol2) 

808 

809 # TODO: Use solveset here 

810 try: 

811 solved_constants = solve(subs_sols, constants, dict=True) 

812 except NotImplementedError: 

813 solved_constants = [] 

814 

815 # XXX: We can't differentiate between the solution not existing because of 

816 # invalid initial conditions, and not existing because solve is not smart 

817 # enough. If we could use solveset, this might be improvable, but for now, 

818 # we use NotImplementedError in this case. 

819 if not solved_constants: 

820 raise ValueError("Couldn't solve for initial conditions") 

821 

822 if solved_constants == True: 

823 raise ValueError("Initial conditions did not produce any solutions for constants. Perhaps they are degenerate.") 

824 

825 if len(solved_constants) > 1: 

826 raise NotImplementedError("Initial conditions produced too many solutions for constants") 

827 

828 return solved_constants[0] 

829 

830def classify_ode(eq, func=None, dict=False, ics=None, **kwargs): 

831 r""" 

832 Returns a tuple of possible :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` 

833 classifications for an ODE. 

834 

835 The tuple is ordered so that first item is the classification that 

836 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` uses to solve the ODE by default. In 

837 general, classifications at the near the beginning of the list will 

838 produce better solutions faster than those near the end, thought there are 

839 always exceptions. To make :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` use a 

840 different classification, use ``dsolve(ODE, func, 

841 hint=<classification>)``. See also the 

842 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` docstring for different meta-hints 

843 you can use. 

844 

845 If ``dict`` is true, :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode` will 

846 return a dictionary of ``hint:match`` expression terms. This is intended 

847 for internal use by :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`. Note that 

848 because dictionaries are ordered arbitrarily, this will most likely not be 

849 in the same order as the tuple. 

850 

851 You can get help on different hints by executing 

852 ``help(ode.ode_hintname)``, where ``hintname`` is the name of the hint 

853 without ``_Integral``. 

854 

855 See :py:data:`~sympy.solvers.ode.allhints` or the 

856 :py:mod:`~sympy.solvers.ode` docstring for a list of all supported hints 

857 that can be returned from :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.classify_ode`. 

858 

859 Notes 

860 ===== 

861 

862 These are remarks on hint names. 

863 

864 ``_Integral`` 

865 

866 If a classification has ``_Integral`` at the end, it will return the 

867 expression with an unevaluated :py:class:`~sympy.integrals.Integral` 

868 class in it. Note that a hint may do this anyway if 

869 :py:meth:`~sympy.core.expr.Expr.integrate` cannot do the integral, 

870 though just using an ``_Integral`` will do so much faster. Indeed, an 

871 ``_Integral`` hint will always be faster than its corresponding hint 

872 without ``_Integral`` because 

873 :py:meth:`~sympy.core.expr.Expr.integrate` is an expensive routine. 

874 If :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` hangs, it is probably because 

875 :py:meth:`~sympy.core.expr.Expr.integrate` is hanging on a tough or 

876 impossible integral. Try using an ``_Integral`` hint or 

877 ``all_Integral`` to get it return something. 

878 

879 Note that some hints do not have ``_Integral`` counterparts. This is 

880 because :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.integrate` is not used in solving 

881 the ODE for those method. For example, `n`\th order linear homogeneous 

882 ODEs with constant coefficients do not require integration to solve, 

883 so there is no ``nth_linear_homogeneous_constant_coeff_Integrate`` 

884 hint. You can easily evaluate any unevaluated 

885 :py:class:`~sympy.integrals.Integral`\s in an expression by doing 

886 ``expr.doit()``. 

887 

888 Ordinals 

889 

890 Some hints contain an ordinal such as ``1st_linear``. This is to help 

891 differentiate them from other hints, as well as from other methods 

892 that may not be implemented yet. If a hint has ``nth`` in it, such as 

893 the ``nth_linear`` hints, this means that the method used to applies 

894 to ODEs of any order. 

895 

896 ``indep`` and ``dep`` 

897 

898 Some hints contain the words ``indep`` or ``dep``. These reference 

899 the independent variable and the dependent function, respectively. For 

900 example, if an ODE is in terms of `f(x)`, then ``indep`` will refer to 

901 `x` and ``dep`` will refer to `f`. 

902 

903 ``subs`` 

904 

905 If a hints has the word ``subs`` in it, it means the the ODE is solved 

906 by substituting the expression given after the word ``subs`` for a 

907 single dummy variable. This is usually in terms of ``indep`` and 

908 ``dep`` as above. The substituted expression will be written only in 

909 characters allowed for names of Python objects, meaning operators will 

910 be spelled out. For example, ``indep``/``dep`` will be written as 

911 ``indep_div_dep``. 

912 

913 ``coeff`` 

914 

915 The word ``coeff`` in a hint refers to the coefficients of something 

916 in the ODE, usually of the derivative terms. See the docstring for 

917 the individual methods for more info (``help(ode)``). This is 

918 contrast to ``coefficients``, as in ``undetermined_coefficients``, 

919 which refers to the common name of a method. 

920 

921 ``_best`` 

922 

923 Methods that have more than one fundamental way to solve will have a 

924 hint for each sub-method and a ``_best`` meta-classification. This 

925 will evaluate all hints and return the best, using the same 

926 considerations as the normal ``best`` meta-hint. 

927 

928 

929 Examples 

930 ======== 

931 

932 >>> from sympy import Function, classify_ode, Eq 

933 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

934 >>> f = Function('f') 

935 >>> classify_ode(Eq(f(x).diff(x), 0), f(x)) 

936 ('nth_algebraic', 'separable', '1st_linear', '1st_homogeneous_coeff_best', 

937 '1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep', 

938 '1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep', 

939 '1st_power_series', 'lie_group', 

940 'nth_linear_constant_coeff_homogeneous', 

941 'nth_linear_euler_eq_homogeneous', 'nth_algebraic_Integral', 

942 'separable_Integral', '1st_linear_Integral', 

943 '1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep_Integral', 

944 '1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep_Integral') 

945 >>> classify_ode(f(x).diff(x, 2) + 3*f(x).diff(x) + 2*f(x) - 4) 

946 ('nth_linear_constant_coeff_undetermined_coefficients', 

947 'nth_linear_constant_coeff_variation_of_parameters', 

948 'nth_linear_constant_coeff_variation_of_parameters_Integral') 

949 

950 """ 

951 ics = sympify(ics) 

952 

953 prep = kwargs.pop('prep', True) 

954 

955 if func and len(func.args) != 1: 

956 raise ValueError("dsolve() and classify_ode() only " 

957 "work with functions of one variable, not %s" % func) 

958 if prep or func is None: 

959 eq, func_ = _preprocess(eq, func) 

960 if func is None: 

961 func = func_ 

962 x = func.args[0] 

963 f = func.func 

964 y = Dummy('y') 

965 xi = kwargs.get('xi') 

966 eta = kwargs.get('eta') 

967 terms = kwargs.get('n') 

968 

969 if isinstance(eq, Equality): 

970 if eq.rhs != 0: 

971 return classify_ode(eq.lhs - eq.rhs, func, dict=dict, ics=ics, xi=xi, 

972 n=terms, eta=eta, prep=False) 

973 eq = eq.lhs 

974 order = ode_order(eq, f(x)) 

975 # hint:matchdict or hint:(tuple of matchdicts) 

976 # Also will contain "default":<default hint> and "order":order items. 

977 matching_hints = {"order": order} 

978 

979 if not order: 

980 if dict: 

981 matching_hints["default"] = None 

982 return matching_hints 

983 else: 

984 return () 

985 

986 df = f(x).diff(x) 

987 a = Wild('a', exclude=[f(x)]) 

988 b = Wild('b', exclude=[f(x)]) 

989 c = Wild('c', exclude=[f(x)]) 

990 d = Wild('d', exclude=[df, f(x).diff(x, 2)]) 

991 e = Wild('e', exclude=[df]) 

992 k = Wild('k', exclude=[df]) 

993 n = Wild('n', exclude=[x, f(x), df]) 

994 c1 = Wild('c1', exclude=[x]) 

995 a2 = Wild('a2', exclude=[x, f(x), df]) 

996 b2 = Wild('b2', exclude=[x, f(x), df]) 

997 c2 = Wild('c2', exclude=[x, f(x), df]) 

998 d2 = Wild('d2', exclude=[x, f(x), df]) 

999 a3 = Wild('a3', exclude=[f(x), df, f(x).diff(x, 2)]) 

1000 b3 = Wild('b3', exclude=[f(x), df, f(x).diff(x, 2)]) 

1001 c3 = Wild('c3', exclude=[f(x), df, f(x).diff(x, 2)]) 

1002 r3 = {'xi': xi, 'eta': eta} # Used for the lie_group hint 

1003 boundary = {} # Used to extract initial conditions 

1004 C1 = Symbol("C1") 

1005 eq = expand(eq) 

1006 

1007 # Preprocessing to get the initial conditions out 

1008 if ics is not None: 

1009 for funcarg in ics: 

1010 # Separating derivatives 

1011 if isinstance(funcarg, (Subs, Derivative)): 

1012 # f(x).diff(x).subs(x, 0) is a Subs, but f(x).diff(x).subs(x, 

1013 # y) is a Derivative 

1014 if isinstance(funcarg, Subs): 

1015 deriv = funcarg.expr 

1016 old = funcarg.variables[0] 

1017 new = funcarg.point[0] 

1018 elif isinstance(funcarg, Derivative): 

1019 deriv = funcarg 

1020 # No information on this. Just assume it was x 

1021 old = x 

1022 new = funcarg.variables[0] 

1023 

1024 if (isinstance(deriv, Derivative) and isinstance(deriv.args[0], 

1025 AppliedUndef) and deriv.args[0].func == f and 

1026 len(deriv.args[0].args) == 1 and old == x and not 

1027 new.has(x) and all(i == deriv.variables[0] for i in 

1028 deriv.variables) and not ics[funcarg].has(f)): 

1029 

1030 dorder = ode_order(deriv, x) 

1031 temp = 'f' + str(dorder) 

1032 boundary.update({temp: new, temp + 'val': ics[funcarg]}) 

1033 else: 

1034 raise ValueError("Enter valid boundary conditions for Derivatives") 

1035 

1036 

1037 # Separating functions 

1038 elif isinstance(funcarg, AppliedUndef): 

1039 if (funcarg.func == f and len(funcarg.args) == 1 and 

1040 not funcarg.args[0].has(x) and not ics[funcarg].has(f)): 

1041 boundary.update({'f0': funcarg.args[0], 'f0val': ics[funcarg]}) 

1042 else: 

1043 raise ValueError("Enter valid boundary conditions for Function") 

1044 

1045 else: 

1046 raise ValueError("Enter boundary conditions of the form ics={f(point}: value, f(x).diff(x, order).subs(x, point): value}") 

1047 

1048 # Precondition to try remove f(x) from highest order derivative 

1049 reduced_eq = None 

1050 if eq.is_Add: 

1051 deriv_coef = eq.coeff(f(x).diff(x, order)) 

1052 if deriv_coef not in (1, 0): 

1053 r = deriv_coef.match(a*f(x)**c1) 

1054 if r and r[c1]: 

1055 den = f(x)**r[c1] 

1056 reduced_eq = Add(*[arg/den for arg in eq.args]) 

1057 if not reduced_eq: 

1058 reduced_eq = eq 

1059 

1060 if order == 1: 

1061 

1062 ## Linear case: a(x)*y'+b(x)*y+c(x) == 0 

1063 if eq.is_Add: 

1064 ind, dep = reduced_eq.as_independent(f) 

1065 else: 

1066 u = Dummy('u') 

1067 ind, dep = (reduced_eq + u).as_independent(f) 

1068 ind, dep = [tmp.subs(u, 0) for tmp in [ind, dep]] 

1069 r = {a: dep.coeff(df), 

1070 b: dep.coeff(f(x)), 

1071 c: ind} 

1072 # double check f[a] since the preconditioning may have failed 

1073 if not r[a].has(f) and not r[b].has(f) and ( 

1074 r[a]*df + r[b]*f(x) + r[c]).expand() - reduced_eq == 0: 

1075 r['a'] = a 

1076 r['b'] = b 

1077 r['c'] = c 

1078 matching_hints["1st_linear"] = r 

1079 matching_hints["1st_linear_Integral"] = r 

1080 

1081 ## Bernoulli case: a(x)*y'+b(x)*y+c(x)*y**n == 0 

1082 r = collect( 

1083 reduced_eq, f(x), exact=True).match(a*df + b*f(x) + c*f(x)**n) 

1084 if r and r[c] != 0 and r[n] != 1: # See issue 4676 

1085 r['a'] = a 

1086 r['b'] = b 

1087 r['c'] = c 

1088 r['n'] = n 

1089 matching_hints["Bernoulli"] = r 

1090 matching_hints["Bernoulli_Integral"] = r 

1091 

1092 ## Riccati special n == -2 case: a2*y'+b2*y**2+c2*y/x+d2/x**2 == 0 

1093 r = collect(reduced_eq, 

1094 f(x), exact=True).match(a2*df + b2*f(x)**2 + c2*f(x)/x + d2/x**2) 

1095 if r and r[b2] != 0 and (r[c2] != 0 or r[d2] != 0): 

1096 r['a2'] = a2 

1097 r['b2'] = b2 

1098 r['c2'] = c2 

1099 r['d2'] = d2 

1100 matching_hints["Riccati_special_minus2"] = r 

1101 

1102 # NON-REDUCED FORM OF EQUATION matches 

1103 r = collect(eq, df, exact=True).match(d + e * df) 

1104 if r: 

1105 r['d'] = d 

1106 r['e'] = e 

1107 r['y'] = y 

1108 r[d] = r[d].subs(f(x), y) 

1109 r[e] = r[e].subs(f(x), y) 

1110 

1111 # FIRST ORDER POWER SERIES WHICH NEEDS INITIAL CONDITIONS 

1112 # TODO: Hint first order series should match only if d/e is analytic. 

1113 # For now, only d/e and (d/e).diff(arg) is checked for existence at 

1114 # at a given point. 

1115 # This is currently done internally in ode_1st_power_series. 

1116 point = boundary.get('f0', 0) 

1117 value = boundary.get('f0val', C1) 

1118 check = cancel(r[d]/r[e]) 

1119 check1 = check.subs({x: point, y: value}) 

1120 if not check1.has(oo) and not check1.has(zoo) and \ 

1121 not check1.has(NaN) and not check1.has(-oo): 

1122 check2 = (check1.diff(x)).subs({x: point, y: value}) 

1123 if not check2.has(oo) and not check2.has(zoo) and \ 

1124 not check2.has(NaN) and not check2.has(-oo): 

1125 rseries = r.copy() 

1126 rseries.update({'terms': terms, 'f0': point, 'f0val': value}) 

1127 matching_hints["1st_power_series"] = rseries 

1128 

1129 r3.update(r) 

1130 ## Exact Differential Equation: P(x, y) + Q(x, y)*y' = 0 where 

1131 # dP/dy == dQ/dx 

1132 try: 

1133 if r[d] != 0: 

1134 numerator = simplify(r[d].diff(y) - r[e].diff(x)) 

1135 # The following few conditions try to convert a non-exact 

1136 # differential equation into an exact one. 

1137 # References : Differential equations with applications 

1138 # and historical notes - George E. Simmons 

1139 

1140 if numerator: 

1141 # If (dP/dy - dQ/dx) / Q = f(x) 

1142 # then exp(integral(f(x))*equation becomes exact 

1143 factor = simplify(numerator/r[e]) 

1144 variables = factor.free_symbols 

1145 if len(variables) == 1 and x == variables.pop(): 

1146 factor = exp(Integral(factor).doit()) 

1147 r[d] *= factor 

1148 r[e] *= factor 

1149 matching_hints["1st_exact"] = r 

1150 matching_hints["1st_exact_Integral"] = r 

1151 else: 

1152 # If (dP/dy - dQ/dx) / -P = f(y) 

1153 # then exp(integral(f(y))*equation becomes exact 

1154 factor = simplify(-numerator/r[d]) 

1155 variables = factor.free_symbols 

1156 if len(variables) == 1 and y == variables.pop(): 

1157 factor = exp(Integral(factor).doit()) 

1158 r[d] *= factor 

1159 r[e] *= factor 

1160 matching_hints["1st_exact"] = r 

1161 matching_hints["1st_exact_Integral"] = r 

1162 else: 

1163 matching_hints["1st_exact"] = r 

1164 matching_hints["1st_exact_Integral"] = r 

1165 

1166 except NotImplementedError: 

1167 # Differentiating the coefficients might fail because of things 

1168 # like f(2*x).diff(x). See issue 4624 and issue 4719. 

1169 pass 

1170 

1171 # Any first order ODE can be ideally solved by the Lie Group 

1172 # method 

1173 matching_hints["lie_group"] = r3 

1174 

1175 # This match is used for several cases below; we now collect on 

1176 # f(x) so the matching works. 

1177 r = collect(reduced_eq, df, exact=True).match(d + e*df) 

1178 if r: 

1179 # Using r[d] and r[e] without any modification for hints 

1180 # linear-coefficients and separable-reduced. 

1181 num, den = r[d], r[e] # ODE = d/e + df 

1182 r['d'] = d 

1183 r['e'] = e 

1184 r['y'] = y 

1185 r[d] = num.subs(f(x), y) 

1186 r[e] = den.subs(f(x), y) 

1187 

1188 ## Separable Case: y' == P(y)*Q(x) 

1189 r[d] = separatevars(r[d]) 

1190 r[e] = separatevars(r[e]) 

1191 # m1[coeff]*m1[x]*m1[y] + m2[coeff]*m2[x]*m2[y]*y' 

1192 m1 = separatevars(r[d], dict=True, symbols=(x, y)) 

1193 m2 = separatevars(r[e], dict=True, symbols=(x, y)) 

1194 if m1 and m2: 

1195 r1 = {'m1': m1, 'm2': m2, 'y': y} 

1196 matching_hints["separable"] = r1 

1197 matching_hints["separable_Integral"] = r1 

1198 

1199 ## First order equation with homogeneous coefficients: 

1200 # dy/dx == F(y/x) or dy/dx == F(x/y) 

1201 ordera = homogeneous_order(r[d], x, y) 

1202 if ordera is not None: 

1203 orderb = homogeneous_order(r[e], x, y) 

1204 if ordera == orderb: 

1205 # u1=y/x and u2=x/y 

1206 u1 = Dummy('u1') 

1207 u2 = Dummy('u2') 

1208 s = "1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs" 

1209 s1 = s + "_dep_div_indep" 

1210 s2 = s + "_indep_div_dep" 

1211 if simplify((r[d] + u1*r[e]).subs({x: 1, y: u1})) != 0: 

1212 matching_hints[s1] = r 

1213 matching_hints[s1 + "_Integral"] = r 

1214 if simplify((r[e] + u2*r[d]).subs({x: u2, y: 1})) != 0: 

1215 matching_hints[s2] = r 

1216 matching_hints[s2 + "_Integral"] = r 

1217 if s1 in matching_hints and s2 in matching_hints: 

1218 matching_hints["1st_homogeneous_coeff_best"] = r 

1219 

1220 ## Linear coefficients of the form 

1221 # y'+ F((a*x + b*y + c)/(a'*x + b'y + c')) = 0 

1222 # that can be reduced to homogeneous form. 

1223 F = num/den 

1224 params = _linear_coeff_match(F, func) 

1225 if params: 

1226 xarg, yarg = params 

1227 u = Dummy('u') 

1228 t = Dummy('t') 

1229 # Dummy substitution for df and f(x). 

1230 dummy_eq = reduced_eq.subs(((df, t), (f(x), u))) 

1231 reps = ((x, x + xarg), (u, u + yarg), (t, df), (u, f(x))) 

1232 dummy_eq = simplify(dummy_eq.subs(reps)) 

1233 # get the re-cast values for e and d 

1234 r2 = collect(expand(dummy_eq), [df, f(x)]).match(e*df + d) 

1235 if r2: 

1236 orderd = homogeneous_order(r2[d], x, f(x)) 

1237 if orderd is not None: 

1238 ordere = homogeneous_order(r2[e], x, f(x)) 

1239 if orderd == ordere: 

1240 # Match arguments are passed in such a way that it 

1241 # is coherent with the already existing homogeneous 

1242 # functions. 

1243 r2[d] = r2[d].subs(f(x), y) 

1244 r2[e] = r2[e].subs(f(x), y) 

1245 r2.update({'xarg': xarg, 'yarg': yarg, 

1246 'd': d, 'e': e, 'y': y}) 

1247 matching_hints["linear_coefficients"] = r2 

1248 matching_hints["linear_coefficients_Integral"] = r2 

1249 

1250 ## Equation of the form y' + (y/x)*H(x^n*y) = 0 

1251 # that can be reduced to separable form 

1252 

1253 factor = simplify(x/f(x)*num/den) 

1254 

1255 # Try representing factor in terms of x^n*y 

1256 # where n is lowest power of x in factor; 

1257 # first remove terms like sqrt(2)*3 from factor.atoms(Mul) 

1258 u = None 

1259 for mul in ordered(factor.atoms(Mul)): 

1260 if mul.has(x): 

1261 _, u = mul.as_independent(x, f(x)) 

1262 break 

1263 if u and u.has(f(x)): 

1264 h = x**(degree(Poly(u.subs(f(x), y), gen=x)))*f(x) 

1265 p = Wild('p') 

1266 if (u/h == 1) or ((u/h).simplify().match(x**p)): 

1267 t = Dummy('t') 

1268 r2 = {'t': t} 

1269 xpart, ypart = u.as_independent(f(x)) 

1270 test = factor.subs(((u, t), (1/u, 1/t))) 

1271 free = test.free_symbols 

1272 if len(free) == 1 and free.pop() == t: 

1273 r2.update({'power': xpart.as_base_exp()[1], 'u': test}) 

1274 matching_hints["separable_reduced"] = r2 

1275 matching_hints["separable_reduced_Integral"] = r2 

1276 

1277 ## Almost-linear equation of the form f(x)*g(y)*y' + k(x)*l(y) + m(x) = 0 

1278 r = collect(eq, [df, f(x)]).match(e*df + d) 

1279 if r: 

1280 r2 = r.copy() 

1281 r2[c] = S.Zero 

1282 if r2[d].is_Add: 

1283 # Separate the terms having f(x) to r[d] and 

1284 # remaining to r[c] 

1285 no_f, r2[d] = r2[d].as_independent(f(x)) 

1286 r2[c] += no_f 

1287 factor = simplify(r2[d].diff(f(x))/r[e]) 

1288 if factor and not factor.has(f(x)): 

1289 r2[d] = factor_terms(r2[d]) 

1290 u = r2[d].as_independent(f(x), as_Add=False)[1] 

1291 r2.update({'a': e, 'b': d, 'c': c, 'u': u}) 

1292 r2[d] /= u 

1293 r2[e] /= u.diff(f(x)) 

1294 matching_hints["almost_linear"] = r2 

1295 matching_hints["almost_linear_Integral"] = r2 

1296 

1297 

1298 elif order == 2: 

1299 # Liouville ODE in the form 

1300 # f(x).diff(x, 2) + g(f(x))*(f(x).diff(x))**2 + h(x)*f(x).diff(x) 

1301 # See Goldstein and Braun, "Advanced Methods for the Solution of 

1302 # Differential Equations", pg. 98 

1303 

1304 s = d*f(x).diff(x, 2) + e*df**2 + k*df 

1305 r = reduced_eq.match(s) 

1306 if r and r[d] != 0: 

1307 y = Dummy('y') 

1308 g = simplify(r[e]/r[d]).subs(f(x), y) 

1309 h = simplify(r[k]/r[d]).subs(f(x), y) 

1310 if y in h.free_symbols or x in g.free_symbols: 

1311 pass 

1312 else: 

1313 r = {'g': g, 'h': h, 'y': y} 

1314 matching_hints["Liouville"] = r 

1315 matching_hints["Liouville_Integral"] = r 

1316 

1317 # Homogeneous second order differential equation of the form 

1318 # a3*f(x).diff(x, 2) + b3*f(x).diff(x) + c3, where 

1319 # for simplicity, a3, b3 and c3 are assumed to be polynomials. 

1320 # It has a definite power series solution at point x0 if, b3/a3 and c3/a3 

1321 # are analytic at x0. 

1322 deq = a3*(f(x).diff(x, 2)) + b3*df + c3*f(x) 

1323 r = collect(reduced_eq, 

1324 [f(x).diff(x, 2), f(x).diff(x), f(x)]).match(deq) 

1325 ordinary = False 

1326 if r and r[a3] != 0: 

1327 if all([r[key].is_polynomial() for key in r]): 

1328 p = cancel(r[b3]/r[a3]) # Used below 

1329 q = cancel(r[c3]/r[a3]) # Used below 

1330 point = kwargs.get('x0', 0) 

1331 check = p.subs(x, point) 

1332 if not check.has(oo) and not check.has(NaN) and \ 

1333 not check.has(zoo) and not check.has(-oo): 

1334 check = q.subs(x, point) 

1335 if not check.has(oo) and not check.has(NaN) and \ 

1336 not check.has(zoo) and not check.has(-oo): 

1337 ordinary = True 

1338 r.update({'a3': a3, 'b3': b3, 'c3': c3, 'x0': point, 'terms': terms}) 

1339 matching_hints["2nd_power_series_ordinary"] = r 

1340 

1341 # Checking if the differential equation has a regular singular point 

1342 # at x0. It has a regular singular point at x0, if (b3/a3)*(x - x0) 

1343 # and (c3/a3)*((x - x0)**2) are analytic at x0. 

1344 if not ordinary: 

1345 p = cancel((x - point)*p) 

1346 check = p.subs(x, point) 

1347 if not check.has(oo) and not check.has(NaN) and \ 

1348 not check.has(zoo) and not check.has(-oo): 

1349 q = cancel(((x - point)**2)*q) 

1350 check = q.subs(x, point) 

1351 if not check.has(oo) and not check.has(NaN) and \ 

1352 not check.has(zoo) and not check.has(-oo): 

1353 coeff_dict = {'p': p, 'q': q, 'x0': point, 'terms': terms} 

1354 matching_hints["2nd_power_series_regular"] = coeff_dict 

1355 

1356 

1357 if order > 0: 

1358 # Any ODE that can be solved with a substitution and 

1359 # repeated integration e.g.: 

1360 # `d^2/dx^2(y) + x*d/dx(y) = constant 

1361 #f'(x) must be finite for this to work 

1362 r = _nth_order_reducible_match(reduced_eq, func) 

1363 if r: 

1364 matching_hints['nth_order_reducible'] = r 

1365 

1366 # Any ODE that can be solved with a combination of algebra and 

1367 # integrals e.g.: 

1368 # d^3/dx^3(x y) = F(x) 

1369 r = _nth_algebraic_match(reduced_eq, func) 

1370 if r['solutions']: 

1371 matching_hints['nth_algebraic'] = r 

1372 matching_hints['nth_algebraic_Integral'] = r 

1373 

1374 # nth order linear ODE 

1375 # a_n(x)y^(n) + ... + a_1(x)y' + a_0(x)y = F(x) = b 

1376 

1377 r = _nth_linear_match(reduced_eq, func, order) 

1378 

1379 # Constant coefficient case (a_i is constant for all i) 

1380 if r and not any(r[i].has(x) for i in r if i >= 0): 

1381 # Inhomogeneous case: F(x) is not identically 0 

1382 if r[-1]: 

1383 undetcoeff = _undetermined_coefficients_match(r[-1], x) 

1384 s = "nth_linear_constant_coeff_variation_of_parameters" 

1385 matching_hints[s] = r 

1386 matching_hints[s + "_Integral"] = r 

1387 if undetcoeff['test']: 

1388 r['trialset'] = undetcoeff['trialset'] 

1389 matching_hints[ 

1390 "nth_linear_constant_coeff_undetermined_coefficients" 

1391 ] = r 

1392 

1393 # Homogeneous case: F(x) is identically 0 

1394 else: 

1395 matching_hints["nth_linear_constant_coeff_homogeneous"] = r 

1396 

1397 # nth order Euler equation a_n*x**n*y^(n) + ... + a_1*x*y' + a_0*y = F(x) 

1398 #In case of Homogeneous euler equation F(x) = 0 

1399 def _test_term(coeff, order): 

1400 r""" 

1401 Linear Euler ODEs have the form K*x**order*diff(y(x),x,order) = F(x), 

1402 where K is independent of x and y(x), order>= 0. 

1403 So we need to check that for each term, coeff == K*x**order from 

1404 some K. We have a few cases, since coeff may have several 

1405 different types. 

1406 """ 

1407 if order < 0: 

1408 raise ValueError("order should be greater than 0") 

1409 if coeff == 0: 

1410 return True 

1411 if order == 0: 

1412 if x in coeff.free_symbols: 

1413 return False 

1414 return True 

1415 if coeff.is_Mul: 

1416 if coeff.has(f(x)): 

1417 return False 

1418 return x**order in coeff.args 

1419 elif coeff.is_Pow: 

1420 return coeff.as_base_exp() == (x, order) 

1421 elif order == 1: 

1422 return x == coeff 

1423 return False 

1424 

1425 # Find coefficient for higest derivative, multiply coefficients to 

1426 # bring the equation into Euler form if possible 

1427 r_rescaled = None 

1428 if r is not None: 

1429 coeff = r[order] 

1430 factor = x**order / coeff 

1431 r_rescaled = {i: factor*r[i] for i in r} 

1432 

1433 if r_rescaled and not any(not _test_term(r_rescaled[i], i) for i in 

1434 r_rescaled if i != 'trialset' and i >= 0): 

1435 if not r_rescaled[-1]: 

1436 matching_hints["nth_linear_euler_eq_homogeneous"] = r_rescaled 

1437 else: 

1438 matching_hints["nth_linear_euler_eq_nonhomogeneous_variation_of_parameters"] = r_rescaled 

1439 matching_hints["nth_linear_euler_eq_nonhomogeneous_variation_of_parameters_Integral"] = r_rescaled 

1440 e, re = posify(r_rescaled[-1].subs(x, exp(x))) 

1441 undetcoeff = _undetermined_coefficients_match(e.subs(re), x) 

1442 if undetcoeff['test']: 

1443 r_rescaled['trialset'] = undetcoeff['trialset'] 

1444 matching_hints["nth_linear_euler_eq_nonhomogeneous_undetermined_coefficients"] = r_rescaled 

1445 

1446 

1447 # Order keys based on allhints. 

1448 retlist = [i for i in allhints if i in matching_hints] 

1449 

1450 if dict: 

1451 # Dictionaries are ordered arbitrarily, so make note of which 

1452 # hint would come first for dsolve(). Use an ordered dict in Py 3. 

1453 matching_hints["default"] = retlist[0] if retlist else None 

1454 matching_hints["ordered_hints"] = tuple(retlist) 

1455 return matching_hints 

1456 else: 

1457 return tuple(retlist) 

1458 

1459def classify_sysode(eq, funcs=None, **kwargs): 

1460 r""" 

1461 Returns a dictionary of parameter names and values that define the system 

1462 of ordinary differential equations in ``eq``. 

1463 The parameters are further used in 

1464 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` for solving that system. 

1465 

1466 The parameter names and values are: 

1467 

1468 'is_linear' (boolean), which tells whether the given system is linear. 

1469 Note that "linear" here refers to the operator: terms such as ``x*diff(x,t)`` are 

1470 nonlinear, whereas terms like ``sin(t)*diff(x,t)`` are still linear operators. 

1471 

1472 'func' (list) contains the :py:class:`~sympy.core.function.Function`s that 

1473 appear with a derivative in the ODE, i.e. those that we are trying to solve 

1474 the ODE for. 

1475 

1476 'order' (dict) with the maximum derivative for each element of the 'func' 

1477 parameter. 

1478 

1479 'func_coeff' (dict) with the coefficient for each triple ``(equation number, 

1480 function, order)```. The coefficients are those subexpressions that do not 

1481 appear in 'func', and hence can be considered constant for purposes of ODE 

1482 solving. 

1483 

1484 'eq' (list) with the equations from ``eq``, sympified and transformed into 

1485 expressions (we are solving for these expressions to be zero). 

1486 

1487 'no_of_equations' (int) is the number of equations (same as ``len(eq)``). 

1488 

1489 'type_of_equation' (string) is an internal classification of the type of 

1490 ODE. 

1491 

1492 References 

1493 ========== 

1494 -http://eqworld.ipmnet.ru/en/solutions/sysode/sode-toc1.htm 

1495 -A. D. Polyanin and A. V. Manzhirov, Handbook of Mathematics for Engineers and Scientists 

1496 

1497 Examples 

1498 ======== 

1499 

1500 >>> from sympy import Function, Eq, symbols, diff 

1501 >>> from sympy.solvers.ode import classify_sysode 

1502 >>> from sympy.abc import t 

1503 >>> f, x, y = symbols('f, x, y', cls=Function) 

1504 >>> k, l, m, n = symbols('k, l, m, n', Integer=True) 

1505 >>> x1 = diff(x(t), t) ; y1 = diff(y(t), t) 

1506 >>> x2 = diff(x(t), t, t) ; y2 = diff(y(t), t, t) 

1507 >>> eq = (Eq(5*x1, 12*x(t) - 6*y(t)), Eq(2*y1, 11*x(t) + 3*y(t))) 

1508 >>> classify_sysode(eq) 

1509 {'eq': [-12*x(t) + 6*y(t) + 5*Derivative(x(t), t), -11*x(t) - 3*y(t) + 2*Derivative(y(t), t)], 

1510 'func': [x(t), y(t)], 'func_coeff': {(0, x(t), 0): -12, (0, x(t), 1): 5, (0, y(t), 0): 6, 

1511 (0, y(t), 1): 0, (1, x(t), 0): -11, (1, x(t), 1): 0, (1, y(t), 0): -3, (1, y(t), 1): 2}, 

1512 'is_linear': True, 'no_of_equation': 2, 'order': {x(t): 1, y(t): 1}, 'type_of_equation': 'type1'} 

1513 >>> eq = (Eq(diff(x(t),t), 5*t*x(t) + t**2*y(t)), Eq(diff(y(t),t), -t**2*x(t) + 5*t*y(t))) 

1514 >>> classify_sysode(eq) 

1515 {'eq': [-t**2*y(t) - 5*t*x(t) + Derivative(x(t), t), t**2*x(t) - 5*t*y(t) + Derivative(y(t), t)], 

1516 'func': [x(t), y(t)], 'func_coeff': {(0, x(t), 0): -5*t, (0, x(t), 1): 1, (0, y(t), 0): -t**2, 

1517 (0, y(t), 1): 0, (1, x(t), 0): t**2, (1, x(t), 1): 0, (1, y(t), 0): -5*t, (1, y(t), 1): 1}, 

1518 'is_linear': True, 'no_of_equation': 2, 'order': {x(t): 1, y(t): 1}, 'type_of_equation': 'type4'} 

1519 

1520 """ 

1521 

1522 # Sympify equations and convert iterables of equations into 

1523 # a list of equations 

1524 def _sympify(eq): 

1525 return list(map(sympify, eq if iterable(eq) else [eq])) 

1526 

1527 eq, funcs = (_sympify(w) for w in [eq, funcs]) 

1528 for i, fi in enumerate(eq): 

1529 if isinstance(fi, Equality): 

1530 eq[i] = fi.lhs - fi.rhs 

1531 matching_hints = {"no_of_equation":i+1} 

1532 matching_hints['eq'] = eq 

1533 if i==0: 

1534 raise ValueError("classify_sysode() works for systems of ODEs. " 

1535 "For scalar ODEs, classify_ode should be used") 

1536 t = list(list(eq[0].atoms(Derivative))[0].atoms(Symbol))[0] 

1537 

1538 # find all the functions if not given 

1539 order = dict() 

1540 if funcs==[None]: 

1541 funcs = [] 

1542 for eqs in eq: 

1543 derivs = eqs.atoms(Derivative) 

1544 func = set().union(*[d.atoms(AppliedUndef) for d in derivs]) 

1545 for func_ in func: 

1546 funcs.append(func_) 

1547 funcs = list(set(funcs)) 

1548 if len(funcs) != len(eq): 

1549 raise ValueError("Number of functions given is not equal to the number of equations %s" % funcs) 

1550 func_dict = dict() 

1551 for func in funcs: 

1552 if not order.get(func, False): 

1553 max_order = 0 

1554 for i, eqs_ in enumerate(eq): 

1555 order_ = ode_order(eqs_,func) 

1556 if max_order < order_: 

1557 max_order = order_ 

1558 eq_no = i 

1559 if eq_no in func_dict: 

1560 list_func = [] 

1561 list_func.append(func_dict[eq_no]) 

1562 list_func.append(func) 

1563 func_dict[eq_no] = list_func 

1564 else: 

1565 func_dict[eq_no] = func 

1566 order[func] = max_order 

1567 funcs = [func_dict[i] for i in range(len(func_dict))] 

1568 matching_hints['func'] = funcs 

1569 for func in funcs: 

1570 if isinstance(func, list): 

1571 for func_elem in func: 

1572 if len(func_elem.args) != 1: 

1573 raise ValueError("dsolve() and classify_sysode() work with " 

1574 "functions of one variable only, not %s" % func) 

1575 else: 

1576 if func and len(func.args) != 1: 

1577 raise ValueError("dsolve() and classify_sysode() work with " 

1578 "functions of one variable only, not %s" % func) 

1579 

1580 # find the order of all equation in system of odes 

1581 matching_hints["order"] = order 

1582 

1583 # find coefficients of terms f(t), diff(f(t),t) and higher derivatives 

1584 # and similarly for other functions g(t), diff(g(t),t) in all equations. 

1585 # Here j denotes the equation number, funcs[l] denotes the function about 

1586 # which we are talking about and k denotes the order of function funcs[l] 

1587 # whose coefficient we are calculating. 

1588 def linearity_check(eqs, j, func, is_linear_): 

1589 for k in range(order[func] + 1): 

1590 func_coef[j, func, k] = collect(eqs.expand(), [diff(func, t, k)]).coeff(diff(func, t, k)) 

1591 if is_linear_ == True: 

1592 if func_coef[j, func, k] == 0: 

1593 if k == 0: 

1594 coef = eqs.as_independent(func, as_Add=True)[1] 

1595 for xr in range(1, ode_order(eqs,func) + 1): 

1596 coef -= eqs.as_independent(diff(func, t, xr), as_Add=True)[1] 

1597 if coef != 0: 

1598 is_linear_ = False 

1599 else: 

1600 if eqs.as_independent(diff(func, t, k), as_Add=True)[1]: 

1601 is_linear_ = False 

1602 else: 

1603 for func_ in funcs: 

1604 if isinstance(func_, list): 

1605 for elem_func_ in func_: 

1606 dep = func_coef[j, func, k].as_independent(elem_func_, as_Add=True)[1] 

1607 if dep != 0: 

1608 is_linear_ = False 

1609 else: 

1610 dep = func_coef[j, func, k].as_independent(func_, as_Add=True)[1] 

1611 if dep != 0: 

1612 is_linear_ = False 

1613 return is_linear_ 

1614 

1615 func_coef = {} 

1616 is_linear = True 

1617 for j, eqs in enumerate(eq): 

1618 for func in funcs: 

1619 if isinstance(func, list): 

1620 for func_elem in func: 

1621 is_linear = linearity_check(eqs, j, func_elem, is_linear) 

1622 else: 

1623 is_linear = linearity_check(eqs, j, func, is_linear) 

1624 matching_hints['func_coeff'] = func_coef 

1625 matching_hints['is_linear'] = is_linear 

1626 

1627 if len(set(order.values()))==1: 

1628 order_eq = list(matching_hints['order'].values())[0] 

1629 if matching_hints['is_linear'] == True: 

1630 if matching_hints['no_of_equation'] == 2: 

1631 if order_eq == 1: 

1632 type_of_equation = check_linear_2eq_order1(eq, funcs, func_coef) 

1633 elif order_eq == 2: 

1634 type_of_equation = check_linear_2eq_order2(eq, funcs, func_coef) 

1635 else: 

1636 type_of_equation = None 

1637 

1638 elif matching_hints['no_of_equation'] == 3: 

1639 if order_eq == 1: 

1640 type_of_equation = check_linear_3eq_order1(eq, funcs, func_coef) 

1641 if type_of_equation==None: 

1642 type_of_equation = check_linear_neq_order1(eq, funcs, func_coef) 

1643 else: 

1644 type_of_equation = None 

1645 else: 

1646 if order_eq == 1: 

1647 type_of_equation = check_linear_neq_order1(eq, funcs, func_coef) 

1648 else: 

1649 type_of_equation = None 

1650 else: 

1651 if matching_hints['no_of_equation'] == 2: 

1652 if order_eq == 1: 

1653 type_of_equation = check_nonlinear_2eq_order1(eq, funcs, func_coef) 

1654 else: 

1655 type_of_equation = None 

1656 elif matching_hints['no_of_equation'] == 3: 

1657 if order_eq == 1: 

1658 type_of_equation = check_nonlinear_3eq_order1(eq, funcs, func_coef) 

1659 else: 

1660 type_of_equation = None 

1661 else: 

1662 type_of_equation = None 

1663 else: 

1664 type_of_equation = None 

1665 

1666 matching_hints['type_of_equation'] = type_of_equation 

1667 

1668 return matching_hints 

1669 

1670 

1671def check_linear_2eq_order1(eq, func, func_coef): 

1672 x = func[0].func 

1673 y = func[1].func 

1674 fc = func_coef 

1675 t = list(list(eq[0].atoms(Derivative))[0].atoms(Symbol))[0] 

1676 r = dict() 

1677 # for equations Eq(a1*diff(x(t),t), b1*x(t) + c1*y(t) + d1) 

1678 # and Eq(a2*diff(y(t),t), b2*x(t) + c2*y(t) + d2) 

1679 r['a1'] = fc[0,x(t),1] ; r['a2'] = fc[1,y(t),1] 

1680 r['b1'] = -fc[0,x(t),0]/fc[0,x(t),1] ; r['b2'] = -fc[1,x(t),0]/fc[1,y(t),1] 

1681 r['c1'] = -fc[0,y(t),0]/fc[0,x(t),1] ; r['c2'] = -fc[1,y(t),0]/fc[1,y(t),1] 

1682 forcing = [S(0),S(0)] 

1683 for i in range(2): 

1684 for j in Add.make_args(eq[i]): 

1685 if not j.has(x(t), y(t)): 

1686 forcing[i] += j 

1687 if not (forcing[0].has(t) or forcing[1].has(t)): 

1688 # We can handle homogeneous case and simple constant forcings 

1689 r['d1'] = forcing[0] 

1690 r['d2'] = forcing[1] 

1691 else: 

1692 # Issue #9244: nonhomogeneous linear systems are not supported 

1693 return None 

1694 

1695 # Conditions to check for type 6 whose equations are Eq(diff(x(t),t), f(t)*x(t) + g(t)*y(t)) and 

1696 # Eq(diff(y(t),t), a*[f(t) + a*h(t)]x(t) + a*[g(t) - h(t)]*y(t)) 

1697 p = 0 

1698 q = 0 

1699 p1 = cancel(r['b2']/(cancel(r['b2']/r['c2']).as_numer_denom()[0])) 

1700 p2 = cancel(r['b1']/(cancel(r['b1']/r['c1']).as_numer_denom()[0])) 

1701 for n, i in enumerate([p1, p2]): 

1702 for j in Mul.make_args(collect_const(i)): 

1703 if not j.has(t): 

1704 q = j 

1705 if q and n==0: 

1706 if ((r['b2']/j - r['b1'])/(r['c1'] - r['c2']/j)) == j: 

1707 p = 1 

1708 elif q and n==1: 

1709 if ((r['b1']/j - r['b2'])/(r['c2'] - r['c1']/j)) == j: 

1710 p = 2 

1711 # End of condition for type 6 

1712 

1713 if r['d1']!=0 or r['d2']!=0: 

1714 if not r['d1'].has(t) and not r['d2'].has(t): 

1715 if all(not r[k].has(t) for k in 'a1 a2 b1 b2 c1 c2'.split()): 

1716 # Equations for type 2 are Eq(a1*diff(x(t),t),b1*x(t)+c1*y(t)+d1) and Eq(a2*diff(y(t),t),b2*x(t)+c2*y(t)+d2) 

1717 return "type2" 

1718 else: 

1719 return None 

1720 else: 

1721 if all(not r[k].has(t) for k in 'a1 a2 b1 b2 c1 c2'.split()): 

1722 # Equations for type 1 are Eq(a1*diff(x(t),t),b1*x(t)+c1*y(t)) and Eq(a2*diff(y(t),t),b2*x(t)+c2*y(t)) 

1723 return "type1" 

1724 else: 

1725 r['b1'] = r['b1']/r['a1'] ; r['b2'] = r['b2']/r['a2'] 

1726 r['c1'] = r['c1']/r['a1'] ; r['c2'] = r['c2']/r['a2'] 

1727 if (r['b1'] == r['c2']) and (r['c1'] == r['b2']): 

1728 # Equation for type 3 are Eq(diff(x(t),t), f(t)*x(t) + g(t)*y(t)) and Eq(diff(y(t),t), g(t)*x(t) + f(t)*y(t)) 

1729 return "type3" 

1730 elif (r['b1'] == r['c2']) and (r['c1'] == -r['b2']) or (r['b1'] == -r['c2']) and (r['c1'] == r['b2']): 

1731 # Equation for type 4 are Eq(diff(x(t),t), f(t)*x(t) + g(t)*y(t)) and Eq(diff(y(t),t), -g(t)*x(t) + f(t)*y(t)) 

1732 return "type4" 

1733 elif (not cancel(r['b2']/r['c1']).has(t) and not cancel((r['c2']-r['b1'])/r['c1']).has(t)) \ 

1734 or (not cancel(r['b1']/r['c2']).has(t) and not cancel((r['c1']-r['b2'])/r['c2']).has(t)): 

1735 # Equations for type 5 are Eq(diff(x(t),t), f(t)*x(t) + g(t)*y(t)) and Eq(diff(y(t),t), a*g(t)*x(t) + [f(t) + b*g(t)]*y(t) 

1736 return "type5" 

1737 elif p: 

1738 return "type6" 

1739 else: 

1740 # Equations for type 7 are Eq(diff(x(t),t), f(t)*x(t) + g(t)*y(t)) and Eq(diff(y(t),t), h(t)*x(t) + p(t)*y(t)) 

1741 return "type7" 

1742 

1743def check_linear_2eq_order2(eq, func, func_coef): 

1744 x = func[0].func 

1745 y = func[1].func 

1746 fc = func_coef 

1747 t = list(list(eq[0].atoms(Derivative))[0].atoms(Symbol))[0] 

1748 r = dict() 

1749 a = Wild('a', exclude=[1/t]) 

1750 b = Wild('b', exclude=[1/t**2]) 

1751 u = Wild('u', exclude=[t, t**2]) 

1752 v = Wild('v', exclude=[t, t**2]) 

1753 w = Wild('w', exclude=[t, t**2]) 

1754 p = Wild('p', exclude=[t, t**2]) 

1755 r['a1'] = fc[0,x(t),2] ; r['a2'] = fc[1,y(t),2] 

1756 r['b1'] = fc[0,x(t),1] ; r['b2'] = fc[1,x(t),1] 

1757 r['c1'] = fc[0,y(t),1] ; r['c2'] = fc[1,y(t),1] 

1758 r['d1'] = fc[0,x(t),0] ; r['d2'] = fc[1,x(t),0] 

1759 r['e1'] = fc[0,y(t),0] ; r['e2'] = fc[1,y(t),0] 

1760 const = [S(0), S(0)] 

1761 for i in range(2): 

1762 for j in Add.make_args(eq[i]): 

1763 if not (j.has(x(t)) or j.has(y(t))): 

1764 const[i] += j 

1765 r['f1'] = const[0] 

1766 r['f2'] = const[1] 

1767 if r['f1']!=0 or r['f2']!=0: 

1768 if all(not r[k].has(t) for k in 'a1 a2 d1 d2 e1 e2 f1 f2'.split()) \ 

1769 and r['b1']==r['c1']==r['b2']==r['c2']==0: 

1770 return "type2" 

1771 

1772 elif all(not r[k].has(t) for k in 'a1 a2 b1 b2 c1 c2 d1 d2 e1 e1'.split()): 

1773 p = [S(0), S(0)] ; q = [S(0), S(0)] 

1774 for n, e in enumerate([r['f1'], r['f2']]): 

1775 if e.has(t): 

1776 tpart = e.as_independent(t, Mul)[1] 

1777 for i in Mul.make_args(tpart): 

1778 if i.has(exp): 

1779 b, e = i.as_base_exp() 

1780 co = e.coeff(t) 

1781 if co and not co.has(t) and co.has(I): 

1782 p[n] = 1 

1783 else: 

1784 q[n] = 1 

1785 else: 

1786 q[n] = 1 

1787 else: 

1788 q[n] = 1 

1789 

1790 if p[0]==1 and p[1]==1 and q[0]==0 and q[1]==0: 

1791 return "type4" 

1792 else: 

1793 return None 

1794 else: 

1795 return None 

1796 else: 

1797 if r['b1']==r['b2']==r['c1']==r['c2']==0 and all(not r[k].has(t) \ 

1798 for k in 'a1 a2 d1 d2 e1 e2'.split()): 

1799 return "type1" 

1800 

1801 elif r['b1']==r['e1']==r['c2']==r['d2']==0 and all(not r[k].has(t) \ 

1802 for k in 'a1 a2 b2 c1 d1 e2'.split()) and r['c1'] == -r['b2'] and \ 

1803 r['d1'] == r['e2']: 

1804 return "type3" 

1805 

1806 elif cancel(-r['b2']/r['d2'])==t and cancel(-r['c1']/r['e1'])==t and not \ 

1807 (r['d2']/r['a2']).has(t) and not (r['e1']/r['a1']).has(t) and \ 

1808 r['b1']==r['d1']==r['c2']==r['e2']==0: 

1809 return "type5" 

1810 

1811 elif ((r['a1']/r['d1']).expand()).match((p*(u*t**2+v*t+w)**2).expand()) and not \ 

1812 (cancel(r['a1']*r['d2']/(r['a2']*r['d1']))).has(t) and not (r['d1']/r['e1']).has(t) and not \ 

1813 (r['d2']/r['e2']).has(t) and r['b1'] == r['b2'] == r['c1'] == r['c2'] == 0: 

1814 return "type10" 

1815 

1816 elif not cancel(r['d1']/r['e1']).has(t) and not cancel(r['d2']/r['e2']).has(t) and not \ 

1817 cancel(r['d1']*r['a2']/(r['d2']*r['a1'])).has(t) and r['b1']==r['b2']==r['c1']==r['c2']==0: 

1818 return "type6" 

1819 

1820 elif not cancel(r['b1']/r['c1']).has(t) and not cancel(r['b2']/r['c2']).has(t) and not \ 

1821 cancel(r['b1']*r['a2']/(r['b2']*r['a1'])).has(t) and r['d1']==r['d2']==r['e1']==r['e2']==0: 

1822 return "type7" 

1823 

1824 elif cancel(-r['b2']/r['d2'])==t and cancel(-r['c1']/r['e1'])==t and not \ 

1825 cancel(r['e1']*r['a2']/(r['d2']*r['a1'])).has(t) and r['e1'].has(t) \ 

1826 and r['b1']==r['d1']==r['c2']==r['e2']==0: 

1827 return "type8" 

1828 

1829 elif (r['b1']/r['a1']).match(a/t) and (r['b2']/r['a2']).match(a/t) and not \ 

1830 (r['b1']/r['c1']).has(t) and not (r['b2']/r['c2']).has(t) and \ 

1831 (r['d1']/r['a1']).match(b/t**2) and (r['d2']/r['a2']).match(b/t**2) \ 

1832 and not (r['d1']/r['e1']).has(t) and not (r['d2']/r['e2']).has(t): 

1833 return "type9" 

1834 

1835 elif -r['b1']/r['d1']==-r['c1']/r['e1']==-r['b2']/r['d2']==-r['c2']/r['e2']==t: 

1836 return "type11" 

1837 

1838 else: 

1839 return None 

1840 

1841def check_linear_3eq_order1(eq, func, func_coef): 

1842 x = func[0].func 

1843 y = func[1].func 

1844 z = func[2].func 

1845 fc = func_coef 

1846 t = list(list(eq[0].atoms(Derivative))[0].atoms(Symbol))[0] 

1847 r = dict() 

1848 r['a1'] = fc[0,x(t),1]; r['a2'] = fc[1,y(t),1]; r['a3'] = fc[2,z(t),1] 

1849 r['b1'] = fc[0,x(t),0]; r['b2'] = fc[1,x(t),0]; r['b3'] = fc[2,x(t),0] 

1850 r['c1'] = fc[0,y(t),0]; r['c2'] = fc[1,y(t),0]; r['c3'] = fc[2,y(t),0] 

1851 r['d1'] = fc[0,z(t),0]; r['d2'] = fc[1,z(t),0]; r['d3'] = fc[2,z(t),0] 

1852 forcing = [S(0), S(0), S(0)] 

1853 for i in range(3): 

1854 for j in Add.make_args(eq[i]): 

1855 if not j.has(x(t), y(t), z(t)): 

1856 forcing[i] += j 

1857 if forcing[0].has(t) or forcing[1].has(t) or forcing[2].has(t): 

1858 # We can handle homogeneous case and simple constant forcings. 

1859 # Issue #9244: nonhomogeneous linear systems are not supported 

1860 return None 

1861 

1862 if all(not r[k].has(t) for k in 'a1 a2 a3 b1 b2 b3 c1 c2 c3 d1 d2 d3'.split()): 

1863 if r['c1']==r['d1']==r['d2']==0: 

1864 return 'type1' 

1865 elif r['c1'] == -r['b2'] and r['d1'] == -r['b3'] and r['d2'] == -r['c3'] \
