1866 and r['b1'] == r['c2'] == r['d3'] == 0: 

1867 return 'type2' 

1868 elif r['b1'] == r['c2'] == r['d3'] == 0 and r['c1']/r['a1'] == -r['d1']/r['a1'] \ 

1869 and r['d2']/r['a2'] == -r['b2']/r['a2'] and r['b3']/r['a3'] == -r['c3']/r['a3']: 

1870 return 'type3' 

1871 else: 

1872 return None 

1873 else: 

1874 for k1 in 'c1 d1 b2 d2 b3 c3'.split(): 

1875 if r[k1] == 0: 

1876 continue 

1877 else: 

1878 if all(not cancel(r[k1]/r[k]).has(t) for k in 'd1 b2 d2 b3 c3'.split() if r[k]!=0) \ 

1879 and all(not cancel(r[k1]/(r['b1'] - r[k])).has(t) for k in 'b1 c2 d3'.split() if r['b1']!=r[k]): 

1880 return 'type4' 

1881 else: 

1882 break 

1883 return None 

1884 

1885def check_linear_neq_order1(eq, func, func_coef): 

1886 x = func[0].func 

1887 y = func[1].func 

1888 z = func[2].func 

1889 fc = func_coef 

1890 t = list(list(eq[0].atoms(Derivative))[0].atoms(Symbol))[0] 

1891 r = dict() 

1892 n = len(eq) 

1893 for i in range(n): 

1894 for j in range(n): 

1895 if (fc[i,func[j],0]/fc[i,func[i],1]).has(t): 

1896 return None 

1897 if len(eq)==3: 

1898 return 'type6' 

1899 return 'type1' 

1900 

1901def check_nonlinear_2eq_order1(eq, func, func_coef): 

1902 t = list(list(eq[0].atoms(Derivative))[0].atoms(Symbol))[0] 

1903 f = Wild('f') 

1904 g = Wild('g') 

1905 u, v = symbols('u, v', cls=Dummy) 

1906 def check_type(x, y): 

1907 r1 = eq[0].match(t*diff(x(t),t) - x(t) + f) 

1908 r2 = eq[1].match(t*diff(y(t),t) - y(t) + g) 

1909 if not (r1 and r2): 

1910 r1 = eq[0].match(diff(x(t),t) - x(t)/t + f/t) 

1911 r2 = eq[1].match(diff(y(t),t) - y(t)/t + g/t) 

1912 if not (r1 and r2): 

1913 r1 = (-eq[0]).match(t*diff(x(t),t) - x(t) + f) 

1914 r2 = (-eq[1]).match(t*diff(y(t),t) - y(t) + g) 

1915 if not (r1 and r2): 

1916 r1 = (-eq[0]).match(diff(x(t),t) - x(t)/t + f/t) 

1917 r2 = (-eq[1]).match(diff(y(t),t) - y(t)/t + g/t) 

1918 if r1 and r2 and not (r1[f].subs(diff(x(t),t),u).subs(diff(y(t),t),v).has(t) \ 

1919 or r2[g].subs(diff(x(t),t),u).subs(diff(y(t),t),v).has(t)): 

1920 return 'type5' 

1921 else: 

1922 return None 

1923 for func_ in func: 

1924 if isinstance(func_, list): 

1925 x = func[0][0].func 

1926 y = func[0][1].func 

1927 eq_type = check_type(x, y) 

1928 if not eq_type: 

1929 eq_type = check_type(y, x) 

1930 return eq_type 

1931 x = func[0].func 

1932 y = func[1].func 

1933 fc = func_coef 

1934 n = Wild('n', exclude=[x(t),y(t)]) 

1935 f1 = Wild('f1', exclude=[v,t]) 

1936 f2 = Wild('f2', exclude=[v,t]) 

1937 g1 = Wild('g1', exclude=[u,t]) 

1938 g2 = Wild('g2', exclude=[u,t]) 

1939 for i in range(2): 

1940 eqs = 0 

1941 for terms in Add.make_args(eq[i]): 

1942 eqs += terms/fc[i,func[i],1] 

1943 eq[i] = eqs 

1944 r = eq[0].match(diff(x(t),t) - x(t)**n*f) 

1945 if r: 

1946 g = (diff(y(t),t) - eq[1])/r[f] 

1947 if r and not (g.has(x(t)) or g.subs(y(t),v).has(t) or r[f].subs(x(t),u).subs(y(t),v).has(t)): 

1948 return 'type1' 

1949 r = eq[0].match(diff(x(t),t) - exp(n*x(t))*f) 

1950 if r: 

1951 g = (diff(y(t),t) - eq[1])/r[f] 

1952 if r and not (g.has(x(t)) or g.subs(y(t),v).has(t) or r[f].subs(x(t),u).subs(y(t),v).has(t)): 

1953 return 'type2' 

1954 g = Wild('g') 

1955 r1 = eq[0].match(diff(x(t),t) - f) 

1956 r2 = eq[1].match(diff(y(t),t) - g) 

1957 if r1 and r2 and not (r1[f].subs(x(t),u).subs(y(t),v).has(t) or \ 

1958 r2[g].subs(x(t),u).subs(y(t),v).has(t)): 

1959 return 'type3' 

1960 r1 = eq[0].match(diff(x(t),t) - f) 

1961 r2 = eq[1].match(diff(y(t),t) - g) 

1962 num, den = ( 

1963 (r1[f].subs(x(t),u).subs(y(t),v))/ 

1964 (r2[g].subs(x(t),u).subs(y(t),v))).as_numer_denom() 

1965 R1 = num.match(f1*g1) 

1966 R2 = den.match(f2*g2) 

1967 phi = (r1[f].subs(x(t),u).subs(y(t),v))/num 

1968 if R1 and R2: 

1969 return 'type4' 

1970 return None 

1971 

1972 

1973def check_nonlinear_2eq_order2(eq, func, func_coef): 

1974 return None 

1975 

1976def check_nonlinear_3eq_order1(eq, func, func_coef): 

1977 x = func[0].func 

1978 y = func[1].func 

1979 z = func[2].func 

1980 fc = func_coef 

1981 t = list(list(eq[0].atoms(Derivative))[0].atoms(Symbol))[0] 

1982 u, v, w = symbols('u, v, w', cls=Dummy) 

1983 a = Wild('a', exclude=[x(t), y(t), z(t), t]) 

1984 b = Wild('b', exclude=[x(t), y(t), z(t), t]) 

1985 c = Wild('c', exclude=[x(t), y(t), z(t), t]) 

1986 f = Wild('f') 

1987 F1 = Wild('F1') 

1988 F2 = Wild('F2') 

1989 F3 = Wild('F3') 

1990 for i in range(3): 

1991 eqs = 0 

1992 for terms in Add.make_args(eq[i]): 

1993 eqs += terms/fc[i,func[i],1] 

1994 eq[i] = eqs 

1995 r1 = eq[0].match(diff(x(t),t) - a*y(t)*z(t)) 

1996 r2 = eq[1].match(diff(y(t),t) - b*z(t)*x(t)) 

1997 r3 = eq[2].match(diff(z(t),t) - c*x(t)*y(t)) 

1998 if r1 and r2 and r3: 

1999 num1, den1 = r1[a].as_numer_denom() 

2000 num2, den2 = r2[b].as_numer_denom() 

2001 num3, den3 = r3[c].as_numer_denom() 

2002 if solve([num1*u-den1*(v-w), num2*v-den2*(w-u), num3*w-den3*(u-v)],[u, v]): 

2003 return 'type1' 

2004 r = eq[0].match(diff(x(t),t) - y(t)*z(t)*f) 

2005 if r: 

2006 r1 = collect_const(r[f]).match(a*f) 

2007 r2 = ((diff(y(t),t) - eq[1])/r1[f]).match(b*z(t)*x(t)) 

2008 r3 = ((diff(z(t),t) - eq[2])/r1[f]).match(c*x(t)*y(t)) 

2009 if r1 and r2 and r3: 

2010 num1, den1 = r1[a].as_numer_denom() 

2011 num2, den2 = r2[b].as_numer_denom() 

2012 num3, den3 = r3[c].as_numer_denom() 

2013 if solve([num1*u-den1*(v-w), num2*v-den2*(w-u), num3*w-den3*(u-v)],[u, v]): 

2014 return 'type2' 

2015 r = eq[0].match(diff(x(t),t) - (F2-F3)) 

2016 if r: 

2017 r1 = collect_const(r[F2]).match(c*F2) 

2018 r1.update(collect_const(r[F3]).match(b*F3)) 

2019 if r1: 

2020 if eq[1].has(r1[F2]) and not eq[1].has(r1[F3]): 

2021 r1[F2], r1[F3] = r1[F3], r1[F2] 

2022 r1[c], r1[b] = -r1[b], -r1[c] 

2023 r2 = eq[1].match(diff(y(t),t) - a*r1[F3] + r1[c]*F1) 

2024 if r2: 

2025 r3 = (eq[2] == diff(z(t),t) - r1[b]*r2[F1] + r2[a]*r1[F2]) 

2026 if r1 and r2 and r3: 

2027 return 'type3' 

2028 r = eq[0].match(diff(x(t),t) - z(t)*F2 + y(t)*F3) 

2029 if r: 

2030 r1 = collect_const(r[F2]).match(c*F2) 

2031 r1.update(collect_const(r[F3]).match(b*F3)) 

2032 if r1: 

2033 if eq[1].has(r1[F2]) and not eq[1].has(r1[F3]): 

2034 r1[F2], r1[F3] = r1[F3], r1[F2] 

2035 r1[c], r1[b] = -r1[b], -r1[c] 

2036 r2 = (diff(y(t),t) - eq[1]).match(a*x(t)*r1[F3] - r1[c]*z(t)*F1) 

2037 if r2: 

2038 r3 = (diff(z(t),t) - eq[2] == r1[b]*y(t)*r2[F1] - r2[a]*x(t)*r1[F2]) 

2039 if r1 and r2 and r3: 

2040 return 'type4' 

2041 r = (diff(x(t),t) - eq[0]).match(x(t)*(F2 - F3)) 

2042 if r: 

2043 r1 = collect_const(r[F2]).match(c*F2) 

2044 r1.update(collect_const(r[F3]).match(b*F3)) 

2045 if r1: 

2046 if eq[1].has(r1[F2]) and not eq[1].has(r1[F3]): 

2047 r1[F2], r1[F3] = r1[F3], r1[F2] 

2048 r1[c], r1[b] = -r1[b], -r1[c] 

2049 r2 = (diff(y(t),t) - eq[1]).match(y(t)*(a*r1[F3] - r1[c]*F1)) 

2050 if r2: 

2051 r3 = (diff(z(t),t) - eq[2] == z(t)*(r1[b]*r2[F1] - r2[a]*r1[F2])) 

2052 if r1 and r2 and r3: 

2053 return 'type5' 

2054 return None 

2055 

2056def check_nonlinear_3eq_order2(eq, func, func_coef): 

2057 return None 

2058 

2059 

2060def checksysodesol(eqs, sols, func=None): 

2061 r""" 

2062 Substitutes corresponding ``sols`` for each functions into each ``eqs`` and 

2063 checks that the result of substitutions for each equation is ``0``. The 

2064 equations and solutions passed can be any iterable. 

2065 

2066 This only works when each ``sols`` have one function only, like `x(t)` or `y(t)`. 

2067 For each function, ``sols`` can have a single solution or a list of solutions. 

2068 In most cases it will not be necessary to explicitly identify the function, 

2069 but if the function cannot be inferred from the original equation it 

2070 can be supplied through the ``func`` argument. 

2071 

2072 When a sequence of equations is passed, the same sequence is used to return 

2073 the result for each equation with each function substituted with corresponding 

2074 solutions. 

2075 

2076 It tries the following method to find zero equivalence for each equation: 

2077 

2078 Substitute the solutions for functions, like `x(t)` and `y(t)` into the 

2079 original equations containing those functions. 

2080 This function returns a tuple. The first item in the tuple is ``True`` if 

2081 the substitution results for each equation is ``0``, and ``False`` otherwise. 

2082 The second item in the tuple is what the substitution results in. Each element 

2083 of the ``list`` should always be ``0`` corresponding to each equation if the 

2084 first item is ``True``. Note that sometimes this function may return ``False``, 

2085 but with an expression that is identically equal to ``0``, instead of returning 

2086 ``True``. This is because :py:meth:`~sympy.simplify.simplify.simplify` cannot 

2087 reduce the expression to ``0``. If an expression returned by each function 

2088 vanishes identically, then ``sols`` really is a solution to ``eqs``. 

2089 

2090 If this function seems to hang, it is probably because of a difficult simplification. 

2091 

2092 Examples 

2093 ======== 

2094 

2095 >>> from sympy import Eq, diff, symbols, sin, cos, exp, sqrt, S, Function 

2096 >>> from sympy.solvers.ode import checksysodesol 

2097 >>> C1, C2 = symbols('C1:3') 

2098 >>> t = symbols('t') 

2099 >>> x, y = symbols('x, y', cls=Function) 

2100 >>> eq = (Eq(diff(x(t),t), x(t) + y(t) + 17), Eq(diff(y(t),t), -2*x(t) + y(t) + 12)) 

2101 >>> sol = [Eq(x(t), (C1*sin(sqrt(2)*t) + C2*cos(sqrt(2)*t))*exp(t) - S(5)/3), 

2102 ... Eq(y(t), (sqrt(2)*C1*cos(sqrt(2)*t) - sqrt(2)*C2*sin(sqrt(2)*t))*exp(t) - S(46)/3)] 

2103 >>> checksysodesol(eq, sol) 

2104 (True, [0, 0]) 

2105 >>> eq = (Eq(diff(x(t),t),x(t)*y(t)**4), Eq(diff(y(t),t),y(t)**3)) 

2106 >>> sol = [Eq(x(t), C1*exp(-1/(4*(C2 + t)))), Eq(y(t), -sqrt(2)*sqrt(-1/(C2 + t))/2), 

2107 ... Eq(x(t), C1*exp(-1/(4*(C2 + t)))), Eq(y(t), sqrt(2)*sqrt(-1/(C2 + t))/2)] 

2108 >>> checksysodesol(eq, sol) 

2109 (True, [0, 0]) 

2110 

2111 """ 

2112 def _sympify(eq): 

2113 return list(map(sympify, eq if iterable(eq) else [eq])) 

2114 eqs = _sympify(eqs) 

2115 for i in range(len(eqs)): 

2116 if isinstance(eqs[i], Equality): 

2117 eqs[i] = eqs[i].lhs - eqs[i].rhs 

2118 if func is None: 

2119 funcs = [] 

2120 for eq in eqs: 

2121 derivs = eq.atoms(Derivative) 

2122 func = set().union(*[d.atoms(AppliedUndef) for d in derivs]) 

2123 for func_ in func: 

2124 funcs.append(func_) 

2125 funcs = list(set(funcs)) 

2126 if not all(isinstance(func, AppliedUndef) and len(func.args) == 1 for func in funcs)\ 

2127 and len({func.args for func in funcs})!=1: 

2128 raise ValueError("func must be a function of one variable, not %s" % func) 

2129 for sol in sols: 

2130 if len(sol.atoms(AppliedUndef)) != 1: 

2131 raise ValueError("solutions should have one function only") 

2132 if len(funcs) != len({sol.lhs for sol in sols}): 

2133 raise ValueError("number of solutions provided does not match the number of equations") 

2134 t = funcs[0].args[0] 

2135 dictsol = dict() 

2136 for sol in sols: 

2137 func = list(sol.atoms(AppliedUndef))[0] 

2138 if sol.rhs == func: 

2139 sol = sol.reversed 

2140 solved = sol.lhs == func and not sol.rhs.has(func) 

2141 if not solved: 

2142 rhs = solve(sol, func) 

2143 if not rhs: 

2144 raise NotImplementedError 

2145 else: 

2146 rhs = sol.rhs 

2147 dictsol[func] = rhs 

2148 checkeq = [] 

2149 for eq in eqs: 

2150 for func in funcs: 

2151 eq = sub_func_doit(eq, func, dictsol[func]) 

2152 ss = simplify(eq) 

2153 if ss != 0: 

2154 eq = ss.expand(force=True) 

2155 else: 

2156 eq = 0 

2157 checkeq.append(eq) 

2158 if len(set(checkeq)) == 1 and list(set(checkeq))[0] == 0: 

2159 return (True, checkeq) 

2160 else: 

2161 return (False, checkeq) 

2162 

2163 

2164@vectorize(0) 

2165def odesimp(ode, eq, func, hint): 

2166 r""" 

2167 Simplifies solutions of ODEs, including trying to solve for ``func`` and 

2168 running :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.constantsimp`. 

2169 

2170 It may use knowledge of the type of solution that the hint returns to 

2171 apply additional simplifications. 

2172 

2173 It also attempts to integrate any :py:class:`~sympy.integrals.Integral`\s 

2174 in the expression, if the hint is not an ``_Integral`` hint. 

2175 

2176 This function should have no effect on expressions returned by 

2177 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`, as 

2178 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` already calls 

2179 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.odesimp`, but the individual hint functions 

2180 do not call :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.odesimp` (because the 

2181 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` wrapper does). Therefore, this 

2182 function is designed for mainly internal use. 

2183 

2184 Examples 

2185 ======== 

2186 

2187 >>> from sympy import sin, symbols, dsolve, pprint, Function 

2188 >>> from sympy.solvers.ode import odesimp 

2189 >>> x , u2, C1= symbols('x,u2,C1') 

2190 >>> f = Function('f') 

2191 

2192 >>> eq = dsolve(x*f(x).diff(x) - f(x) - x*sin(f(x)/x), f(x), 

2193 ... hint='1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep_Integral', 

2194 ... simplify=False) 

2195 >>> pprint(eq, wrap_line=False) 

2196 x 

2197 ---- 

2198 f(x) 

2199 / 

2200 | 

2201 | / 1 \ 

2202 | -|u2 + -------| 

2203 | | /1 \| 

2204 | | sin|--|| 

2205 | \ \u2// 

2206 log(f(x)) = log(C1) + | ---------------- d(u2) 

2207 | 2 

2208 | u2 

2209 | 

2210 / 

2211 

2212 >>> pprint(odesimp(eq, f(x), 1, {C1}, 

2213 ... hint='1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep' 

2214 ... )) #doctest: +SKIP 

2215 x 

2216 --------- = C1 

2217 /f(x)\ 

2218 tan|----| 

2219 \2*x / 

2220 

2221 """ 

2222 x = func.args[0] 

2223 f = func.func 

2224 C1 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=1) 

2225 constants = eq.free_symbols - ode.free_symbols 

2226 

2227 # First, integrate if the hint allows it. 

2228 eq = _handle_Integral(eq, func, hint) 

2229 if hint.startswith("nth_linear_euler_eq_nonhomogeneous"): 

2230 eq = simplify(eq) 

2231 if not isinstance(eq, Equality): 

2232 raise TypeError("eq should be an instance of Equality") 

2233 

2234 # Second, clean up the arbitrary constants. 

2235 # Right now, nth linear hints can put as many as 2*order constants in an 

2236 # expression. If that number grows with another hint, the third argument 

2237 # here should be raised accordingly, or constantsimp() rewritten to handle 

2238 # an arbitrary number of constants. 

2239 eq = constantsimp(eq, constants) 

2240 

2241 # Lastly, now that we have cleaned up the expression, try solving for func. 

2242 # When CRootOf is implemented in solve(), we will want to return a CRootOf 

2243 # every time instead of an Equality. 

2244 

2245 # Get the f(x) on the left if possible. 

2246 if eq.rhs == func and not eq.lhs.has(func): 

2247 eq = [Eq(eq.rhs, eq.lhs)] 

2248 

2249 # make sure we are working with lists of solutions in simplified form. 

2250 if eq.lhs == func and not eq.rhs.has(func): 

2251 # The solution is already solved 

2252 eq = [eq] 

2253 

2254 # special simplification of the rhs 

2255 if hint.startswith("nth_linear_constant_coeff"): 

2256 # Collect terms to make the solution look nice. 

2257 # This is also necessary for constantsimp to remove unnecessary 

2258 # terms from the particular solution from variation of parameters 

2259 # 

2260 # Collect is not behaving reliably here. The results for 

2261 # some linear constant-coefficient equations with repeated 

2262 # roots do not properly simplify all constants sometimes. 

2263 # 'collectterms' gives different orders sometimes, and results 

2264 # differ in collect based on that order. The 

2265 # sort-reverse trick fixes things, but may fail in the 

2266 # future. In addition, collect is splitting exponentials with 

2267 # rational powers for no reason. We have to do a match 

2268 # to fix this using Wilds. 

2269 global collectterms 

2270 try: 

2271 collectterms.sort(key=default_sort_key) 

2272 collectterms.reverse() 

2273 except Exception: 

2274 pass 

2275 assert len(eq) == 1 and eq[0].lhs == f(x) 

2276 sol = eq[0].rhs 

2277 sol = expand_mul(sol) 

2278 for i, reroot, imroot in collectterms: 

2279 sol = collect(sol, x**i*exp(reroot*x)*sin(abs(imroot)*x)) 

2280 sol = collect(sol, x**i*exp(reroot*x)*cos(imroot*x)) 

2281 for i, reroot, imroot in collectterms: 

2282 sol = collect(sol, x**i*exp(reroot*x)) 

2283 del collectterms 

2284 

2285 # Collect is splitting exponentials with rational powers for 

2286 # no reason. We call powsimp to fix. 

2287 sol = powsimp(sol) 

2288 

2289 eq[0] = Eq(f(x), sol) 

2290 

2291 else: 

2292 # The solution is not solved, so try to solve it 

2293 try: 

2294 floats = any(i.is_Float for i in eq.atoms(Number)) 

2295 eqsol = solve(eq, func, force=True, rational=False if floats else None) 

2296 if not eqsol: 

2297 raise NotImplementedError 

2298 except (NotImplementedError, PolynomialError): 

2299 eq = [eq] 

2300 else: 

2301 def _expand(expr): 

2302 numer, denom = expr.as_numer_denom() 

2303 

2304 if denom.is_Add: 

2305 return expr 

2306 else: 

2307 return powsimp(expr.expand(), combine='exp', deep=True) 

2308 

2309 # XXX: the rest of odesimp() expects each ``t`` to be in a 

2310 # specific normal form: rational expression with numerator 

2311 # expanded, but with combined exponential functions (at 

2312 # least in this setup all tests pass). 

2313 eq = [Eq(f(x), _expand(t)) for t in eqsol] 

2314 

2315 # special simplification of the lhs. 

2316 if hint.startswith("1st_homogeneous_coeff"): 

2317 for j, eqi in enumerate(eq): 

2318 newi = logcombine(eqi, force=True) 

2319 if isinstance(newi.lhs, log) and newi.rhs == 0: 

2320 newi = Eq(newi.lhs.args[0]/C1, C1) 

2321 eq[j] = newi 

2322 

2323 # We cleaned up the constants before solving to help the solve engine with 

2324 # a simpler expression, but the solved expression could have introduced 

2325 # things like -C1, so rerun constantsimp() one last time before returning. 

2326 for i, eqi in enumerate(eq): 

2327 eq[i] = constantsimp(eqi, constants) 

2328 eq[i] = constant_renumber(eq[i], ode.free_symbols) 

2329 

2330 # If there is only 1 solution, return it; 

2331 # otherwise return the list of solutions. 

2332 if len(eq) == 1: 

2333 eq = eq[0] 

2334 return eq 

2335 

2336def checkodesol(ode, sol, func=None, order='auto', solve_for_func=True): 

2337 r""" 

2338 Substitutes ``sol`` into ``ode`` and checks that the result is ``0``. 

2339 

2340 This only works when ``func`` is one function, like `f(x)`. ``sol`` can 

2341 be a single solution or a list of solutions. Each solution may be an 

2342 :py:class:`~sympy.core.relational.Equality` that the solution satisfies, 

2343 e.g. ``Eq(f(x), C1), Eq(f(x) + C1, 0)``; or simply an 

2344 :py:class:`~sympy.core.expr.Expr`, e.g. ``f(x) - C1``. In most cases it 

2345 will not be necessary to explicitly identify the function, but if the 

2346 function cannot be inferred from the original equation it can be supplied 

2347 through the ``func`` argument. 

2348 

2349 If a sequence of solutions is passed, the same sort of container will be 

2350 used to return the result for each solution. 

2351 

2352 It tries the following methods, in order, until it finds zero equivalence: 

2353 

2354 1. Substitute the solution for `f` in the original equation. This only 

2355 works if ``ode`` is solved for `f`. It will attempt to solve it first 

2356 unless ``solve_for_func == False``. 

2357 2. Take `n` derivatives of the solution, where `n` is the order of 

2358 ``ode``, and check to see if that is equal to the solution. This only 

2359 works on exact ODEs. 

2360 3. Take the 1st, 2nd, ..., `n`\th derivatives of the solution, each time 

2361 solving for the derivative of `f` of that order (this will always be 

2362 possible because `f` is a linear operator). Then back substitute each 

2363 derivative into ``ode`` in reverse order. 

2364 

2365 This function returns a tuple. The first item in the tuple is ``True`` if 

2366 the substitution results in ``0``, and ``False`` otherwise. The second 

2367 item in the tuple is what the substitution results in. It should always 

2368 be ``0`` if the first item is ``True``. Sometimes this function will 

2369 return ``False`` even when an expression is identically equal to ``0``. 

2370 This happens when :py:meth:`~sympy.simplify.simplify.simplify` does not 

2371 reduce the expression to ``0``. If an expression returned by this 

2372 function vanishes identically, then ``sol`` really is a solution to 

2373 the ``ode``. 

2374 

2375 If this function seems to hang, it is probably because of a hard 

2376 simplification. 

2377 

2378 To use this function to test, test the first item of the tuple. 

2379 

2380 Examples 

2381 ======== 

2382 

2383 >>> from sympy import Eq, Function, checkodesol, symbols 

2384 >>> x, C1 = symbols('x,C1') 

2385 >>> f = Function('f') 

2386 >>> checkodesol(f(x).diff(x), Eq(f(x), C1)) 

2387 (True, 0) 

2388 >>> assert checkodesol(f(x).diff(x), C1)[0] 

2389 >>> assert not checkodesol(f(x).diff(x), x)[0] 

2390 >>> checkodesol(f(x).diff(x, 2), x**2) 

2391 (False, 2) 

2392 

2393 """ 

2394 if not isinstance(ode, Equality): 

2395 ode = Eq(ode, 0) 

2396 if func is None: 

2397 try: 

2398 _, func = _preprocess(ode.lhs) 

2399 except ValueError: 

2400 funcs = [s.atoms(AppliedUndef) for s in ( 

2401 sol if is_sequence(sol, set) else [sol])] 

2402 funcs = set().union(*funcs) 

2403 if len(funcs) != 1: 

2404 raise ValueError( 

2405 'must pass func arg to checkodesol for this case.') 

2406 func = funcs.pop() 

2407 if not isinstance(func, AppliedUndef) or len(func.args) != 1: 

2408 raise ValueError( 

2409 "func must be a function of one variable, not %s" % func) 

2410 if is_sequence(sol, set): 

2411 return type(sol)([checkodesol(ode, i, order=order, solve_for_func=solve_for_func) for i in sol]) 

2412 

2413 if not isinstance(sol, Equality): 

2414 sol = Eq(func, sol) 

2415 elif sol.rhs == func: 

2416 sol = sol.reversed 

2417 

2418 if order == 'auto': 

2419 order = ode_order(ode, func) 

2420 solved = sol.lhs == func and not sol.rhs.has(func) 

2421 if solve_for_func and not solved: 

2422 rhs = solve(sol, func) 

2423 if rhs: 

2424 eqs = [Eq(func, t) for t in rhs] 

2425 if len(rhs) == 1: 

2426 eqs = eqs[0] 

2427 return checkodesol(ode, eqs, order=order, 

2428 solve_for_func=False) 

2429 

2430 s = True 

2431 testnum = 0 

2432 x = func.args[0] 

2433 while s: 

2434 if testnum == 0: 

2435 # First pass, try substituting a solved solution directly into the 

2436 # ODE. This has the highest chance of succeeding. 

2437 ode_diff = ode.lhs - ode.rhs 

2438 

2439 if sol.lhs == func: 

2440 s = sub_func_doit(ode_diff, func, sol.rhs) 

2441 else: 

2442 testnum += 1 

2443 continue 

2444 ss = simplify(s) 

2445 if ss: 

2446 # with the new numer_denom in power.py, if we do a simple 

2447 # expansion then testnum == 0 verifies all solutions. 

2448 s = ss.expand(force=True) 

2449 else: 

2450 s = 0 

2451 testnum += 1 

2452 elif testnum == 1: 

2453 # Second pass. If we cannot substitute f, try seeing if the nth 

2454 # derivative is equal, this will only work for odes that are exact, 

2455 # by definition. 

2456 s = simplify( 

2457 trigsimp(diff(sol.lhs, x, order) - diff(sol.rhs, x, order)) - 

2458 trigsimp(ode.lhs) + trigsimp(ode.rhs)) 

2459 # s2 = simplify( 

2460 # diff(sol.lhs, x, order) - diff(sol.rhs, x, order) - \ 

2461 # ode.lhs + ode.rhs) 

2462 testnum += 1 

2463 elif testnum == 2: 

2464 # Third pass. Try solving for df/dx and substituting that into the 

2465 # ODE. Thanks to Chris Smith for suggesting this method. Many of 

2466 # the comments below are his, too. 

2467 # The method: 

2468 # - Take each of 1..n derivatives of the solution. 

2469 # - Solve each nth derivative for d^(n)f/dx^(n) 

2470 # (the differential of that order) 

2471 # - Back substitute into the ODE in decreasing order 

2472 # (i.e., n, n-1, ...) 

2473 # - Check the result for zero equivalence 

2474 if sol.lhs == func and not sol.rhs.has(func): 

2475 diffsols = {0: sol.rhs} 

2476 elif sol.rhs == func and not sol.lhs.has(func): 

2477 diffsols = {0: sol.lhs} 

2478 else: 

2479 diffsols = {} 

2480 sol = sol.lhs - sol.rhs 

2481 for i in range(1, order + 1): 

2482 # Differentiation is a linear operator, so there should always 

2483 # be 1 solution. Nonetheless, we test just to make sure. 

2484 # We only need to solve once. After that, we automatically 

2485 # have the solution to the differential in the order we want. 

2486 if i == 1: 

2487 ds = sol.diff(x) 

2488 try: 

2489 sdf = solve(ds, func.diff(x, i)) 

2490 if not sdf: 

2491 raise NotImplementedError 

2492 except NotImplementedError: 

2493 testnum += 1 

2494 break 

2495 else: 

2496 diffsols[i] = sdf[0] 

2497 else: 

2498 # This is what the solution says df/dx should be. 

2499 diffsols[i] = diffsols[i - 1].diff(x) 

2500 

2501 # Make sure the above didn't fail. 

2502 if testnum > 2: 

2503 continue 

2504 else: 

2505 # Substitute it into ODE to check for self consistency. 

2506 lhs, rhs = ode.lhs, ode.rhs 

2507 for i in range(order, -1, -1): 

2508 if i == 0 and 0 not in diffsols: 

2509 # We can only substitute f(x) if the solution was 

2510 # solved for f(x). 

2511 break 

2512 lhs = sub_func_doit(lhs, func.diff(x, i), diffsols[i]) 

2513 rhs = sub_func_doit(rhs, func.diff(x, i), diffsols[i]) 

2514 ode_or_bool = Eq(lhs, rhs) 

2515 ode_or_bool = simplify(ode_or_bool) 

2516 

2517 if isinstance(ode_or_bool, (bool, BooleanAtom)): 

2518 if ode_or_bool: 

2519 lhs = rhs = S.Zero 

2520 else: 

2521 lhs = ode_or_bool.lhs 

2522 rhs = ode_or_bool.rhs 

2523 # No sense in overworking simplify -- just prove that the 

2524 # numerator goes to zero 

2525 num = trigsimp((lhs - rhs).as_numer_denom()[0]) 

2526 # since solutions are obtained using force=True we test 

2527 # using the same level of assumptions 

2528 ## replace function with dummy so assumptions will work 

2529 _func = Dummy('func') 

2530 num = num.subs(func, _func) 

2531 ## posify the expression 

2532 num, reps = posify(num) 

2533 s = simplify(num).xreplace(reps).xreplace({_func: func}) 

2534 testnum += 1 

2535 else: 

2536 break 

2537 

2538 if not s: 

2539 return (True, s) 

2540 elif s is True: # The code above never was able to change s 

2541 raise NotImplementedError("Unable to test if " + str(sol) + 

2542 " is a solution to " + str(ode) + ".") 

2543 else: 

2544 return (False, s) 

2545 

2546 

2547def ode_sol_simplicity(sol, func, trysolving=True): 

2548 r""" 

2549 Returns an extended integer representing how simple a solution to an ODE 

2550 is. 

2551 

2552 The following things are considered, in order from most simple to least: 

2553 

2554 - ``sol`` is solved for ``func``. 

2555 - ``sol`` is not solved for ``func``, but can be if passed to solve (e.g., 

2556 a solution returned by ``dsolve(ode, func, simplify=False``). 

2557 - If ``sol`` is not solved for ``func``, then base the result on the 

2558 length of ``sol``, as computed by ``len(str(sol))``. 

2559 - If ``sol`` has any unevaluated :py:class:`~sympy.integrals.Integral`\s, 

2560 this will automatically be considered less simple than any of the above. 

2561 

2562 This function returns an integer such that if solution A is simpler than 

2563 solution B by above metric, then ``ode_sol_simplicity(sola, func) < 

2564 ode_sol_simplicity(solb, func)``. 

2565 

2566 Currently, the following are the numbers returned, but if the heuristic is 

2567 ever improved, this may change. Only the ordering is guaranteed. 

2568 

2569 +----------------------------------------------+-------------------+ 

2570 | Simplicity | Return | 

2571 +==============================================+===================+ 

2572 | ``sol`` solved for ``func`` | ``-2`` | 

2573 +----------------------------------------------+-------------------+ 

2574 | ``sol`` not solved for ``func`` but can be | ``-1`` | 

2575 +----------------------------------------------+-------------------+ 

2576 | ``sol`` is not solved nor solvable for | ``len(str(sol))`` | 

2577 | ``func`` | | 

2578 +----------------------------------------------+-------------------+ 

2579 | ``sol`` contains an | ``oo`` | 

2580 | :py:class:`~sympy.integrals.Integral` | | 

2581 +----------------------------------------------+-------------------+ 

2582 

2583 ``oo`` here means the SymPy infinity, which should compare greater than 

2584 any integer. 

2585 

2586 If you already know :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.solvers.solve` cannot solve 

2587 ``sol``, you can use ``trysolving=False`` to skip that step, which is the 

2588 only potentially slow step. For example, 

2589 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve` with the ``simplify=False`` flag 

2590 should do this. 

2591 

2592 If ``sol`` is a list of solutions, if the worst solution in the list 

2593 returns ``oo`` it returns that, otherwise it returns ``len(str(sol))``, 

2594 that is, the length of the string representation of the whole list. 

2595 

2596 Examples 

2597 ======== 

2598 

2599 This function is designed to be passed to ``min`` as the key argument, 

2600 such as ``min(listofsolutions, key=lambda i: ode_sol_simplicity(i, 

2601 f(x)))``. 

2602 

2603 >>> from sympy import symbols, Function, Eq, tan, cos, sqrt, Integral 

2604 >>> from sympy.solvers.ode import ode_sol_simplicity 

2605 >>> x, C1, C2 = symbols('x, C1, C2') 

2606 >>> f = Function('f') 

2607 

2608 >>> ode_sol_simplicity(Eq(f(x), C1*x**2), f(x)) 

2609 -2 

2610 >>> ode_sol_simplicity(Eq(x**2 + f(x), C1), f(x)) 

2611 -1 

2612 >>> ode_sol_simplicity(Eq(f(x), C1*Integral(2*x, x)), f(x)) 

2613 oo 

2614 >>> eq1 = Eq(f(x)/tan(f(x)/(2*x)), C1) 

2615 >>> eq2 = Eq(f(x)/tan(f(x)/(2*x) + f(x)), C2) 

2616 >>> [ode_sol_simplicity(eq, f(x)) for eq in [eq1, eq2]] 

2617 [28, 35] 

2618 >>> min([eq1, eq2], key=lambda i: ode_sol_simplicity(i, f(x))) 

2619 Eq(f(x)/tan(f(x)/(2*x)), C1) 

2620 

2621 """ 

2622 # TODO: if two solutions are solved for f(x), we still want to be 

2623 # able to get the simpler of the two 

2624 

2625 # See the docstring for the coercion rules. We check easier (faster) 

2626 # things here first, to save time. 

2627 

2628 if iterable(sol): 

2629 # See if there are Integrals 

2630 for i in sol: 

2631 if ode_sol_simplicity(i, func, trysolving=trysolving) == oo: 

2632 return oo 

2633 

2634 return len(str(sol)) 

2635 

2636 if sol.has(Integral): 

2637 return oo 

2638 

2639 # Next, try to solve for func. This code will change slightly when CRootOf 

2640 # is implemented in solve(). Probably a CRootOf solution should fall 

2641 # somewhere between a normal solution and an unsolvable expression. 

2642 

2643 # First, see if they are already solved 

2644 if sol.lhs == func and not sol.rhs.has(func) or \ 

2645 sol.rhs == func and not sol.lhs.has(func): 

2646 return -2 

2647 # We are not so lucky, try solving manually 

2648 if trysolving: 

2649 try: 

2650 sols = solve(sol, func) 

2651 if not sols: 

2652 raise NotImplementedError 

2653 except NotImplementedError: 

2654 pass 

2655 else: 

2656 return -1 

2657 

2658 # Finally, a naive computation based on the length of the string version 

2659 # of the expression. This may favor combined fractions because they 

2660 # will not have duplicate denominators, and may slightly favor expressions 

2661 # with fewer additions and subtractions, as those are separated by spaces 

2662 # by the printer. 

2663 

2664 # Additional ideas for simplicity heuristics are welcome, like maybe 

2665 # checking if a equation has a larger domain, or if constantsimp has 

2666 # introduced arbitrary constants numbered higher than the order of a 

2667 # given ODE that sol is a solution of. 

2668 return len(str(sol)) 

2669 

2670 

2671def _get_constant_subexpressions(expr, Cs): 

2672 Cs = set(Cs) 

2673 Ces = [] 

2674 def _recursive_walk(expr): 

2675 expr_syms = expr.free_symbols 

2676 if expr_syms and expr_syms.issubset(Cs): 

2677 Ces.append(expr) 

2678 else: 

2679 if expr.func == exp: 

2680 expr = expr.expand(mul=True) 

2681 if expr.func in (Add, Mul): 

2682 d = sift(expr.args, lambda i : i.free_symbols.issubset(Cs)) 

2683 if len(d[True]) > 1: 

2684 x = expr.func(*d[True]) 

2685 if not x.is_number: 

2686 Ces.append(x) 

2687 elif isinstance(expr, Integral): 

2688 if expr.free_symbols.issubset(Cs) and \ 

2689 all(len(x) == 3 for x in expr.limits): 

2690 Ces.append(expr) 

2691 for i in expr.args: 

2692 _recursive_walk(i) 

2693 return 

2694 _recursive_walk(expr) 

2695 return Ces 

2696 

2697def __remove_linear_redundancies(expr, Cs): 

2698 cnts = {i: expr.count(i) for i in Cs} 

2699 Cs = [i for i in Cs if cnts[i] > 0] 

2700 

2701 def _linear(expr): 

2702 if isinstance(expr, Add): 

2703 xs = [i for i in Cs if expr.count(i)==cnts[i] \ 

2704 and 0 == expr.diff(i, 2)] 

2705 d = {} 

2706 for x in xs: 

2707 y = expr.diff(x) 

2708 if y not in d: 

2709 d[y]=[] 

2710 d[y].append(x) 

2711 for y in d: 

2712 if len(d[y]) > 1: 

2713 d[y].sort(key=str) 

2714 for x in d[y][1:]: 

2715 expr = expr.subs(x, 0) 

2716 return expr 

2717 

2718 def _recursive_walk(expr): 

2719 if len(expr.args) != 0: 

2720 expr = expr.func(*[_recursive_walk(i) for i in expr.args]) 

2721 expr = _linear(expr) 

2722 return expr 

2723 

2724 if isinstance(expr, Equality): 

2725 lhs, rhs = [_recursive_walk(i) for i in expr.args] 

2726 f = lambda i: isinstance(i, Number) or i in Cs 

2727 if isinstance(lhs, Symbol) and lhs in Cs: 

2728 rhs, lhs = lhs, rhs 

2729 if lhs.func in (Add, Symbol) and rhs.func in (Add, Symbol): 

2730 dlhs = sift([lhs] if isinstance(lhs, AtomicExpr) else lhs.args, f) 

2731 drhs = sift([rhs] if isinstance(rhs, AtomicExpr) else rhs.args, f) 

2732 for i in [True, False]: 

2733 for hs in [dlhs, drhs]: 

2734 if i not in hs: 

2735 hs[i] = [0] 

2736 # this calculation can be simplified 

2737 lhs = Add(*dlhs[False]) - Add(*drhs[False]) 

2738 rhs = Add(*drhs[True]) - Add(*dlhs[True]) 

2739 elif lhs.func in (Mul, Symbol) and rhs.func in (Mul, Symbol): 

2740 dlhs = sift([lhs] if isinstance(lhs, AtomicExpr) else lhs.args, f) 

2741 if True in dlhs: 

2742 if False not in dlhs: 

2743 dlhs[False] = [1] 

2744 lhs = Mul(*dlhs[False]) 

2745 rhs = rhs/Mul(*dlhs[True]) 

2746 return Eq(lhs, rhs) 

2747 else: 

2748 return _recursive_walk(expr) 

2749 

2750@vectorize(0) 

2751def constantsimp(expr, constants): 

2752 r""" 

2753 Simplifies an expression with arbitrary constants in it. 

2754 

2755 This function is written specifically to work with 

2756 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`, and is not intended for general use. 

2757 

2758 Simplification is done by "absorbing" the arbitrary constants into other 

2759 arbitrary constants, numbers, and symbols that they are not independent 

2760 of. 

2761 

2762 The symbols must all have the same name with numbers after it, for 

2763 example, ``C1``, ``C2``, ``C3``. The ``symbolname`` here would be 

2764 '``C``', the ``startnumber`` would be 1, and the ``endnumber`` would be 3. 

2765 If the arbitrary constants are independent of the variable ``x``, then the 

2766 independent symbol would be ``x``. There is no need to specify the 

2767 dependent function, such as ``f(x)``, because it already has the 

2768 independent symbol, ``x``, in it. 

2769 

2770 Because terms are "absorbed" into arbitrary constants and because 

2771 constants are renumbered after simplifying, the arbitrary constants in 

2772 expr are not necessarily equal to the ones of the same name in the 

2773 returned result. 

2774 

2775 If two or more arbitrary constants are added, multiplied, or raised to the 

2776 power of each other, they are first absorbed together into a single 

2777 arbitrary constant. Then the new constant is combined into other terms if 

2778 necessary. 

2779 

2780 Absorption of constants is done with limited assistance: 

2781 

2782 1. terms of :py:class:`~sympy.core.add.Add`\s are collected to try join 

2783 constants so `e^x (C_1 \cos(x) + C_2 \cos(x))` will simplify to `e^x 

2784 C_1 \cos(x)`; 

2785 

2786 2. powers with exponents that are :py:class:`~sympy.core.add.Add`\s are 

2787 expanded so `e^{C_1 + x}` will be simplified to `C_1 e^x`. 

2788 

2789 Use :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.constant_renumber` to renumber constants 

2790 after simplification or else arbitrary numbers on constants may appear, 

2791 e.g. `C_1 + C_3 x`. 

2792 

2793 In rare cases, a single constant can be "simplified" into two constants. 

2794 Every differential equation solution should have as many arbitrary 

2795 constants as the order of the differential equation. The result here will 

2796 be technically correct, but it may, for example, have `C_1` and `C_2` in 

2797 an expression, when `C_1` is actually equal to `C_2`. Use your discretion 

2798 in such situations, and also take advantage of the ability to use hints in 

2799 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.dsolve`. 

2800 

2801 Examples 

2802 ======== 

2803 

2804 >>> from sympy import symbols 

2805 >>> from sympy.solvers.ode import constantsimp 

2806 >>> C1, C2, C3, x, y = symbols('C1, C2, C3, x, y') 

2807 >>> constantsimp(2*C1*x, {C1, C2, C3}) 

2808 C1*x 

2809 >>> constantsimp(C1 + 2 + x, {C1, C2, C3}) 

2810 C1 + x 

2811 >>> constantsimp(C1*C2 + 2 + C2 + C3*x, {C1, C2, C3}) 

2812 C1 + C3*x 

2813 

2814 """ 

2815 # This function works recursively. The idea is that, for Mul, 

2816 # Add, Pow, and Function, if the class has a constant in it, then 

2817 # we can simplify it, which we do by recursing down and 

2818 # simplifying up. Otherwise, we can skip that part of the 

2819 # expression. 

2820 

2821 Cs = constants 

2822 

2823 orig_expr = expr 

2824 

2825 constant_subexprs = _get_constant_subexpressions(expr, Cs) 

2826 for xe in constant_subexprs: 

2827 xes = list(xe.free_symbols) 

2828 if not xes: 

2829 continue 

2830 if all([expr.count(c) == xe.count(c) for c in xes]): 

2831 xes.sort(key=str) 

2832 expr = expr.subs(xe, xes[0]) 

2833 

2834 # try to perform common sub-expression elimination of constant terms 

2835 try: 

2836 commons, rexpr = cse(expr) 

2837 commons.reverse() 

2838 rexpr = rexpr[0] 

2839 for s in commons: 

2840 cs = list(s[1].atoms(Symbol)) 

2841 if len(cs) == 1 and cs[0] in Cs and \ 

2842 cs[0] not in rexpr.atoms(Symbol) and \ 

2843 not any(cs[0] in ex for ex in commons if ex != s): 

2844 rexpr = rexpr.subs(s[0], cs[0]) 

2845 else: 

2846 rexpr = rexpr.subs(*s) 

2847 expr = rexpr 

2848 except Exception: 

2849 pass 

2850 expr = __remove_linear_redundancies(expr, Cs) 

2851 

2852 def _conditional_term_factoring(expr): 

2853 new_expr = terms_gcd(expr, clear=False, deep=True, expand=False) 

2854 

2855 # we do not want to factor exponentials, so handle this separately 

2856 if new_expr.is_Mul: 

2857 infac = False 

2858 asfac = False 

2859 for m in new_expr.args: 

2860 if isinstance(m, exp): 

2861 asfac = True 

2862 elif m.is_Add: 

2863 infac = any(isinstance(fi, exp) for t in m.args 

2864 for fi in Mul.make_args(t)) 

2865 if asfac and infac: 

2866 new_expr = expr 

2867 break 

2868 return new_expr 

2869 

2870 expr = _conditional_term_factoring(expr) 

2871 

2872 # call recursively if more simplification is possible 

2873 if orig_expr != expr: 

2874 return constantsimp(expr, Cs) 

2875 return expr 

2876 

2877 

2878def constant_renumber(expr, variables=None, newconstants=None): 

2879 r""" 

2880 Renumber arbitrary constants in ``expr`` to use the symbol names as given 

2881 in ``newconstants``. In the process, this reorders expression terms in a 

2882 standard way. 

2883 

2884 If ``newconstants`` is not provided then the new constant names will be 

2885 ``C1``, ``C2`` etc. Otherwise ``newconstants`` should be an iterable 

2886 giving the new symbols to use for the constants in order. 

2887 

2888 The ``variables`` argument is a list of non-constant symbols. All other 

2889 free symbols found in ``expr`` are assumed to be constants and will be 

2890 renumbered. If ``variables`` is not given then any numbered symbol 

2891 beginning with ``C`` (e.g. ``C1``) is assumed to be a constant. 

2892 

2893 Symbols are renumbered based on ``.sort_key()``, so they should be 

2894 numbered roughly in the order that they appear in the final, printed 

2895 expression. Note that this ordering is based in part on hashes, so it can 

2896 produce different results on different machines. 

2897 

2898 The structure of this function is very similar to that of 

2899 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.constantsimp`. 

2900 

2901 Examples 

2902 ======== 

2903 

2904 >>> from sympy import symbols, Eq, pprint 

2905 >>> from sympy.solvers.ode import constant_renumber 

2906 >>> x, C1, C2, C3 = symbols('x,C1:4') 

2907 >>> expr = C3 + C2*x + C1*x**2 

2908 >>> expr 

2909 C1*x**2 + C2*x + C3 

2910 >>> constant_renumber(expr) 

2911 C1 + C2*x + C3*x**2 

2912 

2913 The ``variables`` argument specifies which are constants so that the 

2914 other symbols will not be renumbered: 

2915 

2916 >>> constant_renumber(expr, [C1, x]) 

2917 C1*x**2 + C2 + C3*x 

2918 

2919 The ``newconstants`` argument is used to specify what symbols to use when 

2920 replacing the constants: 

2921 

2922 >>> constant_renumber(expr, [x], newconstants=symbols('E1:4')) 

2923 E1 + E2*x + E3*x**2 

2924 

2925 """ 

2926 if type(expr) in (set, list, tuple): 

2927 renumbered = [constant_renumber(e, variables, newconstants) for e in expr] 

2928 return type(expr)(renumbered) 

2929 

2930 # Symbols in solution but not ODE are constants 

2931 if variables is not None: 

2932 variables = set(variables) 

2933 constantsymbols = list(expr.free_symbols - variables) 

2934 # Any Cn is a constant... 

2935 else: 

2936 variables = set() 

2937 isconstant = lambda s: s.startswith('C') and s[1:].isdigit() 

2938 constantsymbols = [sym for sym in expr.free_symbols if isconstant(sym.name)] 

2939 

2940 # Find new constants checking that they aren't alread in the ODE 

2941 if newconstants is None: 

2942 iter_constants = numbered_symbols(start=1, prefix='C', exclude=variables) 

2943 else: 

2944 iter_constants = (sym for sym in newconstants if sym not in variables) 

2945 

2946 global newstartnumber 

2947 newstartnumber = 1 

2948 endnumber = len(constantsymbols) 

2949 constants_found = [None]*(endnumber + 2) 

2950 

2951 # make a mapping to send all constantsymbols to S.One and use 

2952 # that to make sure that term ordering is not dependent on 

2953 # the indexed value of C 

2954 C_1 = [(ci, S.One) for ci in constantsymbols] 

2955 sort_key=lambda arg: default_sort_key(arg.subs(C_1)) 

2956 

2957 def _constant_renumber(expr): 

2958 r""" 

2959 We need to have an internal recursive function so that 

2960 newstartnumber maintains its values throughout recursive calls. 

2961 

2962 """ 

2963 # FIXME: Use nonlocal here when support for Py2 is dropped: 

2964 global newstartnumber 

2965 

2966 if isinstance(expr, Equality): 

2967 return Eq( 

2968 _constant_renumber(expr.lhs), 

2969 _constant_renumber(expr.rhs)) 

2970 

2971 if type(expr) not in (Mul, Add, Pow) and not expr.is_Function and \ 

2972 not expr.has(*constantsymbols): 

2973 # Base case, as above. Hope there aren't constants inside 

2974 # of some other class, because they won't be renumbered. 

2975 return expr 

2976 elif expr.is_Piecewise: 

2977 return expr 

2978 elif expr in constantsymbols: 

2979 if expr not in constants_found: 

2980 constants_found[newstartnumber] = expr 

2981 newstartnumber += 1 

2982 return expr 

2983 elif expr.is_Function or expr.is_Pow or isinstance(expr, Tuple): 

2984 return expr.func( 

2985 *[_constant_renumber(x) for x in expr.args]) 

2986 else: 

2987 sortedargs = list(expr.args) 

2988 sortedargs.sort(key=sort_key) 

2989 return expr.func(*[_constant_renumber(x) for x in sortedargs]) 

2990 expr = _constant_renumber(expr) 

2991 

2992 # Don't renumber symbols present in the ODE. 

2993 constants_found = [c for c in constants_found if c not in variables] 

2994 

2995 # Renumbering happens here 

2996 expr = expr.subs(zip(constants_found[1:], iter_constants), simultaneous=True) 

2997 return expr 

2998 

2999 

3000def _handle_Integral(expr, func, hint): 

3001 r""" 

3002 Converts a solution with Integrals in it into an actual solution. 

3003 

3004 For most hints, this simply runs ``expr.doit()``. 

3005 

3006 """ 

3007 global y 

3008 x = func.args[0] 

3009 f = func.func 

3010 if hint == "1st_exact": 

3011 sol = (expr.doit()).subs(y, f(x)) 

3012 del y 

3013 elif hint == "1st_exact_Integral": 

3014 sol = Eq(Subs(expr.lhs, y, f(x)), expr.rhs) 

3015 del y 

3016 elif hint == "nth_linear_constant_coeff_homogeneous": 

3017 sol = expr 

3018 elif not hint.endswith("_Integral"): 

3019 sol = expr.doit() 

3020 else: 

3021 sol = expr 

3022 return sol 

3023 

3024 

3025# FIXME: replace the general solution in the docstring with 

3026# dsolve(equation, hint='1st_exact_Integral'). You will need to be able 

3027# to have assumptions on P and Q that dP/dy = dQ/dx. 

3028def ode_1st_exact(eq, func, order, match): 

3029 r""" 

3030 Solves 1st order exact ordinary differential equations. 

3031 

3032 A 1st order differential equation is called exact if it is the total 

3033 differential of a function. That is, the differential equation 

3034 

3035 .. math:: P(x, y) \,\partial{}x + Q(x, y) \,\partial{}y = 0 

3036 

3037 is exact if there is some function `F(x, y)` such that `P(x, y) = 

3038 \partial{}F/\partial{}x` and `Q(x, y) = \partial{}F/\partial{}y`. It can 

3039 be shown that a necessary and sufficient condition for a first order ODE 

3040 to be exact is that `\partial{}P/\partial{}y = \partial{}Q/\partial{}x`. 

3041 Then, the solution will be as given below:: 

3042 

3043 >>> from sympy import Function, Eq, Integral, symbols, pprint 

3044 >>> x, y, t, x0, y0, C1= symbols('x,y,t,x0,y0,C1') 

3045 >>> P, Q, F= map(Function, ['P', 'Q', 'F']) 

3046 >>> pprint(Eq(Eq(F(x, y), Integral(P(t, y), (t, x0, x)) + 

3047 ... Integral(Q(x0, t), (t, y0, y))), C1)) 

3048 x y 

3049 / / 

3050 | | 

3051 F(x, y) = | P(t, y) dt + | Q(x0, t) dt = C1 

3052 | | 

3053 / / 

3054 x0 y0 

3055 

3056 Where the first partials of `P` and `Q` exist and are continuous in a 

3057 simply connected region. 

3058 

3059 A note: SymPy currently has no way to represent inert substitution on an 

3060 expression, so the hint ``1st_exact_Integral`` will return an integral 

3061 with `dy`. This is supposed to represent the function that you are 

3062 solving for. 

3063 

3064 Examples 

3065 ======== 

3066 

3067 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, cos, sin 

3068 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3069 >>> f = Function('f') 

3070 >>> dsolve(cos(f(x)) - (x*sin(f(x)) - f(x)**2)*f(x).diff(x), 

3071 ... f(x), hint='1st_exact') 

3072 Eq(x*cos(f(x)) + f(x)**3/3, C1) 

3073 

3074 References 

3075 ========== 

3076 

3077 - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exact_differential_equation 

3078 - M. Tenenbaum & H. Pollard, "Ordinary Differential Equations", 

3079 Dover 1963, pp. 73 

3080 

3081 # indirect doctest 

3082 

3083 """ 

3084 x = func.args[0] 

3085 f = func.func 

3086 r = match # d+e*diff(f(x),x) 

3087 e = r[r['e']] 

3088 d = r[r['d']] 

3089 global y # This is the only way to pass dummy y to _handle_Integral 

3090 y = r['y'] 

3091 C1 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=1) 

3092 # Refer Joel Moses, "Symbolic Integration - The Stormy Decade", 

3093 # Communications of the ACM, Volume 14, Number 8, August 1971, pp. 558 

3094 # which gives the method to solve an exact differential equation. 

3095 sol = Integral(d, x) + Integral((e - (Integral(d, x).diff(y))), y) 

3096 return Eq(sol, C1) 

3097 

3098 

3099def ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_best(eq, func, order, match): 

3100 r""" 

3101 Returns the best solution to an ODE from the two hints 

3102 ``1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep`` and 

3103 ``1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep``. 

3104 

3105 This is as determined by :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_sol_simplicity`. 

3106 

3107 See the 

3108 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep` 

3109 and 

3110 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep` 

3111 docstrings for more information on these hints. Note that there is no 

3112 ``ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_best_Integral`` hint. 

3113 

3114 Examples 

3115 ======== 

3116 

3117 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, pprint 

3118 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3119 >>> f = Function('f') 

3120 >>> pprint(dsolve(2*x*f(x) + (x**2 + f(x)**2)*f(x).diff(x), f(x), 

3121 ... hint='1st_homogeneous_coeff_best', simplify=False)) 

3122 / 2 \ 

3123 | 3*x | 

3124 log|----- + 1| 

3125 | 2 | 

3126 \f (x) / 

3127 log(f(x)) = log(C1) - -------------- 

3128 3 

3129 

3130 References 

3131 ========== 

3132 

3133 - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homogeneous_differential_equation 

3134 - M. Tenenbaum & H. Pollard, "Ordinary Differential Equations", 

3135 Dover 1963, pp. 59 

3136 

3137 # indirect doctest 

3138 

3139 """ 

3140 # There are two substitutions that solve the equation, u1=y/x and u2=x/y 

3141 # They produce different integrals, so try them both and see which 

3142 # one is easier. 

3143 sol1 = ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep(eq, 

3144 func, order, match) 

3145 sol2 = ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep(eq, 

3146 func, order, match) 

3147 simplify = match.get('simplify', True) 

3148 if simplify: 

3149 # why is odesimp called here? Should it be at the usual spot? 

3150 sol1 = odesimp(eq, sol1, func, "1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep") 

3151 sol2 = odesimp(eq, sol2, func, "1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep") 

3152 return min([sol1, sol2], key=lambda x: ode_sol_simplicity(x, func, 

3153 trysolving=not simplify)) 

3154 

3155 

3156def ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep(eq, func, order, match): 

3157 r""" 

3158 Solves a 1st order differential equation with homogeneous coefficients 

3159 using the substitution `u_1 = \frac{\text{<dependent 

3160 variable>}}{\text{<independent variable>}}`. 

3161 

3162 This is a differential equation 

3163 

3164 .. math:: P(x, y) + Q(x, y) dy/dx = 0 

3165 

3166 such that `P` and `Q` are homogeneous and of the same order. A function 

3167 `F(x, y)` is homogeneous of order `n` if `F(x t, y t) = t^n F(x, y)`. 

3168 Equivalently, `F(x, y)` can be rewritten as `G(y/x)` or `H(x/y)`. See 

3169 also the docstring of :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.homogeneous_order`. 

3170 

3171 If the coefficients `P` and `Q` in the differential equation above are 

3172 homogeneous functions of the same order, then it can be shown that the 

3173 substitution `y = u_1 x` (i.e. `u_1 = y/x`) will turn the differential 

3174 equation into an equation separable in the variables `x` and `u`. If 

3175 `h(u_1)` is the function that results from making the substitution `u_1 = 

3176 f(x)/x` on `P(x, f(x))` and `g(u_2)` is the function that results from the 

3177 substitution on `Q(x, f(x))` in the differential equation `P(x, f(x)) + 

3178 Q(x, f(x)) f'(x) = 0`, then the general solution is:: 

3179 

3180 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, pprint 

3181 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3182 >>> f, g, h = map(Function, ['f', 'g', 'h']) 

3183 >>> genform = g(f(x)/x) + h(f(x)/x)*f(x).diff(x) 

3184 >>> pprint(genform) 

3185 /f(x)\ /f(x)\ d 

3186 g|----| + h|----|*--(f(x)) 

3187 \ x / \ x / dx 

3188 >>> pprint(dsolve(genform, f(x), 

3189 ... hint='1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep_Integral')) 

3190 f(x) 

3191 ---- 

3192 x 

3193 / 

3194 | 

3195 | -h(u1) 

3196 log(x) = C1 + | ---------------- d(u1) 

3197 | u1*h(u1) + g(u1) 

3198 | 

3199 / 

3200 

3201 Where `u_1 h(u_1) + g(u_1) \ne 0` and `x \ne 0`. 

3202 

3203 See also the docstrings of 

3204 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_best` and 

3205 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep`. 

3206 

3207 Examples 

3208 ======== 

3209 

3210 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve 

3211 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3212 >>> f = Function('f') 

3213 >>> pprint(dsolve(2*x*f(x) + (x**2 + f(x)**2)*f(x).diff(x), f(x), 

3214 ... hint='1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep', simplify=False)) 

3215 / 3 \ 

3216 |3*f(x) f (x)| 

3217 log|------ + -----| 

3218 | x 3 | 

3219 \ x / 

3220 log(x) = log(C1) - ------------------- 

3221 3 

3222 

3223 References 

3224 ========== 

3225 

3226 - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homogeneous_differential_equation 

3227 - M. Tenenbaum & H. Pollard, "Ordinary Differential Equations", 

3228 Dover 1963, pp. 59 

3229 

3230 # indirect doctest 

3231 

3232 """ 

3233 x = func.args[0] 

3234 f = func.func 

3235 u = Dummy('u') 

3236 u1 = Dummy('u1') # u1 == f(x)/x 

3237 r = match # d+e*diff(f(x),x) 

3238 C1 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=1) 

3239 xarg = match.get('xarg', 0) 

3240 yarg = match.get('yarg', 0) 

3241 int = Integral( 

3242 (-r[r['e']]/(r[r['d']] + u1*r[r['e']])).subs({x: 1, r['y']: u1}), 

3243 (u1, None, f(x)/x)) 

3244 sol = logcombine(Eq(log(x), int + log(C1)), force=True) 

3245 sol = sol.subs(f(x), u).subs(((u, u - yarg), (x, x - xarg), (u, f(x)))) 

3246 return sol 

3247 

3248 

3249def ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep(eq, func, order, match): 

3250 r""" 

3251 Solves a 1st order differential equation with homogeneous coefficients 

3252 using the substitution `u_2 = \frac{\text{<independent 

3253 variable>}}{\text{<dependent variable>}}`. 

3254 

3255 This is a differential equation 

3256 

3257 .. math:: P(x, y) + Q(x, y) dy/dx = 0 

3258 

3259 such that `P` and `Q` are homogeneous and of the same order. A function 

3260 `F(x, y)` is homogeneous of order `n` if `F(x t, y t) = t^n F(x, y)`. 

3261 Equivalently, `F(x, y)` can be rewritten as `G(y/x)` or `H(x/y)`. See 

3262 also the docstring of :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.homogeneous_order`. 

3263 

3264 If the coefficients `P` and `Q` in the differential equation above are 

3265 homogeneous functions of the same order, then it can be shown that the 

3266 substitution `x = u_2 y` (i.e. `u_2 = x/y`) will turn the differential 

3267 equation into an equation separable in the variables `y` and `u_2`. If 

3268 `h(u_2)` is the function that results from making the substitution `u_2 = 

3269 x/f(x)` on `P(x, f(x))` and `g(u_2)` is the function that results from the 

3270 substitution on `Q(x, f(x))` in the differential equation `P(x, f(x)) + 

3271 Q(x, f(x)) f'(x) = 0`, then the general solution is: 

3272 

3273 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, pprint 

3274 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3275 >>> f, g, h = map(Function, ['f', 'g', 'h']) 

3276 >>> genform = g(x/f(x)) + h(x/f(x))*f(x).diff(x) 

3277 >>> pprint(genform) 

3278 / x \ / x \ d 

3279 g|----| + h|----|*--(f(x)) 

3280 \f(x)/ \f(x)/ dx 

3281 >>> pprint(dsolve(genform, f(x), 

3282 ... hint='1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep_Integral')) 

3283 x 

3284 ---- 

3285 f(x) 

3286 / 

3287 | 

3288 | -g(u2) 

3289 | ---------------- d(u2) 

3290 | u2*g(u2) + h(u2) 

3291 | 

3292 / 

3293 <BLANKLINE> 

3294 f(x) = C1*e 

3295 

3296 Where `u_2 g(u_2) + h(u_2) \ne 0` and `f(x) \ne 0`. 

3297 

3298 See also the docstrings of 

3299 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_best` and 

3300 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep`. 

3301 

3302 Examples 

3303 ======== 

3304 

3305 >>> from sympy import Function, pprint, dsolve 

3306 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3307 >>> f = Function('f') 

3308 >>> pprint(dsolve(2*x*f(x) + (x**2 + f(x)**2)*f(x).diff(x), f(x), 

3309 ... hint='1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep', 

3310 ... simplify=False)) 

3311 / 2 \ 

3312 | 3*x | 

3313 log|----- + 1| 

3314 | 2 | 

3315 \f (x) / 

3316 log(f(x)) = log(C1) - -------------- 

3317 3 

3318 

3319 References 

3320 ========== 

3321 

3322 - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homogeneous_differential_equation 

3323 - M. Tenenbaum & H. Pollard, "Ordinary Differential Equations", 

3324 Dover 1963, pp. 59 

3325 

3326 # indirect doctest 

3327 

3328 """ 

3329 x = func.args[0] 

3330 f = func.func 

3331 u = Dummy('u') 

3332 u2 = Dummy('u2') # u2 == x/f(x) 

3333 r = match # d+e*diff(f(x),x) 

3334 C1 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=1) 

3335 xarg = match.get('xarg', 0) # If xarg present take xarg, else zero 

3336 yarg = match.get('yarg', 0) # If yarg present take yarg, else zero 

3337 int = Integral( 

3338 simplify( 

3339 (-r[r['d']]/(r[r['e']] + u2*r[r['d']])).subs({x: u2, r['y']: 1})), 

3340 (u2, None, x/f(x))) 

3341 sol = logcombine(Eq(log(f(x)), int + log(C1)), force=True) 

3342 sol = sol.subs(f(x), u).subs(((u, u - yarg), (x, x - xarg), (u, f(x)))) 

3343 return sol 

3344 

3345# XXX: Should this function maybe go somewhere else? 

3346 

3347 

3348def homogeneous_order(eq, *symbols): 

3349 r""" 

3350 Returns the order `n` if `g` is homogeneous and ``None`` if it is not 

3351 homogeneous. 

3352 

3353 Determines if a function is homogeneous and if so of what order. A 

3354 function `f(x, y, \cdots)` is homogeneous of order `n` if `f(t x, t y, 

3355 \cdots) = t^n f(x, y, \cdots)`. 

3356 

3357 If the function is of two variables, `F(x, y)`, then `f` being homogeneous 

3358 of any order is equivalent to being able to rewrite `F(x, y)` as `G(x/y)` 

3359 or `H(y/x)`. This fact is used to solve 1st order ordinary differential 

3360 equations whose coefficients are homogeneous of the same order (see the 

3361 docstrings of 

3362 :py:meth:`~solvers.ode.ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_dep_div_indep` and 

3363 :py:meth:`~solvers.ode.ode_1st_homogeneous_coeff_subs_indep_div_dep`). 

3364 

3365 Symbols can be functions, but every argument of the function must be a 

3366 symbol, and the arguments of the function that appear in the expression 

3367 must match those given in the list of symbols. If a declared function 

3368 appears with different arguments than given in the list of symbols, 

3369 ``None`` is returned. 

3370 

3371 Examples 

3372 ======== 

3373 

3374 >>> from sympy import Function, homogeneous_order, sqrt 

3375 >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 

3376 >>> f = Function('f') 

3377 >>> homogeneous_order(f(x), f(x)) is None 

3378 True 

3379 >>> homogeneous_order(f(x,y), f(y, x), x, y) is None 

3380 True 

3381 >>> homogeneous_order(f(x), f(x), x) 

3382 1 

3383 >>> homogeneous_order(x**2*f(x)/sqrt(x**2+f(x)**2), x, f(x)) 

3384 2 

3385 >>> homogeneous_order(x**2+f(x), x, f(x)) is None 

3386 True 

3387 

3388 """ 

3389 

3390 if not symbols: 

3391 raise ValueError("homogeneous_order: no symbols were given.") 

3392 symset = set(symbols) 

3393 eq = sympify(eq) 

3394 

3395 # The following are not supported 

3396 if eq.has(Order, Derivative): 

3397 return None 

3398 

3399 # These are all constants 

3400 if (eq.is_Number or 

3401 eq.is_NumberSymbol or 

3402 eq.is_number 

3403 ): 

3404 return S.Zero 

3405 

3406 # Replace all functions with dummy variables 

3407 dum = numbered_symbols(prefix='d', cls=Dummy) 

3408 newsyms = set() 

3409 for i in [j for j in symset if getattr(j, 'is_Function')]: 

3410 iargs = set(i.args) 

3411 if iargs.difference(symset): 

3412 return None 

3413 else: 

3414 dummyvar = next(dum) 

3415 eq = eq.subs(i, dummyvar) 

3416 symset.remove(i) 

3417 newsyms.add(dummyvar) 

3418 symset.update(newsyms) 

3419 

3420 if not eq.free_symbols & symset: 

3421 return None 

3422 

3423 # assuming order of a nested function can only be equal to zero 

3424 if isinstance(eq, Function): 

3425 return None if homogeneous_order( 

3426 eq.args[0], *tuple(symset)) != 0 else S.Zero 

3427 

3428 # make the replacement of x with x*t and see if t can be factored out 

3429 t = Dummy('t', positive=True) # It is sufficient that t > 0 

3430 eqs = separatevars(eq.subs([(i, t*i) for i in symset]), [t], dict=True)[t] 

3431 if eqs is S.One: 

3432 return S.Zero # there was no term with only t 

3433 i, d = eqs.as_independent(t, as_Add=False) 

3434 b, e = d.as_base_exp() 

3435 if b == t: 

3436 return e 

3437 

3438 

3439def ode_1st_linear(eq, func, order, match): 

3440 r""" 

3441 Solves 1st order linear differential equations. 

3442 

3443 These are differential equations of the form 

3444 

3445 .. math:: dy/dx + P(x) y = Q(x)\text{.} 

3446 

3447 These kinds of differential equations can be solved in a general way. The 

3448 integrating factor `e^{\int P(x) \,dx}` will turn the equation into a 

3449 separable equation. The general solution is:: 

3450 

3451 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, Eq, pprint, diff, sin 

3452 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3453 >>> f, P, Q = map(Function, ['f', 'P', 'Q']) 

3454 >>> genform = Eq(f(x).diff(x) + P(x)*f(x), Q(x)) 

3455 >>> pprint(genform) 

3456 d 

3457 P(x)*f(x) + --(f(x)) = Q(x) 

3458 dx 

3459 >>> pprint(dsolve(genform, f(x), hint='1st_linear_Integral')) 

3460 / / \ 

3461 | | | 

3462 | | / | / 

3463 | | | | | 

3464 | | | P(x) dx | - | P(x) dx 

3465 | | | | | 

3466 | | / | / 

3467 f(x) = |C1 + | Q(x)*e dx|*e 

3468 | | | 

3469 \ / / 

3470 

3471 

3472 Examples 

3473 ======== 

3474 

3475 >>> f = Function('f') 

3476 >>> pprint(dsolve(Eq(x*diff(f(x), x) - f(x), x**2*sin(x)), 

3477 ... f(x), '1st_linear')) 

3478 f(x) = x*(C1 - cos(x)) 

3479 

3480 References 

3481 ========== 

3482 

3483 - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_differential_equation#First_order_equation 

3484 - M. Tenenbaum & H. Pollard, "Ordinary Differential Equations", 

3485 Dover 1963, pp. 92 

3486 

3487 # indirect doctest 

3488 

3489 """ 

3490 x = func.args[0] 

3491 f = func.func 

3492 r = match # a*diff(f(x),x) + b*f(x) + c 

3493 C1 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=1) 

3494 t = exp(Integral(r[r['b']]/r[r['a']], x)) 

3495 tt = Integral(t*(-r[r['c']]/r[r['a']]), x) 

3496 f = match.get('u', f(x)) # take almost-linear u if present, else f(x) 

3497 return Eq(f, (tt + C1)/t) 

3498 

3499 

3500def ode_Bernoulli(eq, func, order, match): 

3501 r""" 

3502 Solves Bernoulli differential equations. 

3503 

3504 These are equations of the form 

3505 

3506 .. math:: dy/dx + P(x) y = Q(x) y^n\text{, }n \ne 1`\text{.} 

3507 

3508 The substitution `w = 1/y^{1-n}` will transform an equation of this form 

3509 into one that is linear (see the docstring of 

3510 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_1st_linear`). The general solution is:: 

3511 

3512 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, Eq, pprint 

3513 >>> from sympy.abc import x, n 

3514 >>> f, P, Q = map(Function, ['f', 'P', 'Q']) 

3515 >>> genform = Eq(f(x).diff(x) + P(x)*f(x), Q(x)*f(x)**n) 

3516 >>> pprint(genform) 

3517 d n 

3518 P(x)*f(x) + --(f(x)) = Q(x)*f (x) 

3519 dx 

3520 >>> pprint(dsolve(genform, f(x), hint='Bernoulli_Integral')) #doctest: +SKIP 

3521 1 

3522 ---- 

3523 1 - n 

3524 // / \ \ 

3525 || | | | 

3526 || | / | / | 

3527 || | | | | | 

3528 || | (1 - n)* | P(x) dx | (-1 + n)* | P(x) dx| 

3529 || | | | | | 

3530 || | / | / | 

3531 f(x) = ||C1 + (-1 + n)* | -Q(x)*e dx|*e | 

3532 || | | | 

3533 \\ / / / 

3534 

3535 

3536 Note that the equation is separable when `n = 1` (see the docstring of 

3537 :py:meth:`~sympy.solvers.ode.ode_separable`). 

3538 

3539 >>> pprint(dsolve(Eq(f(x).diff(x) + P(x)*f(x), Q(x)*f(x)), f(x), 

3540 ... hint='separable_Integral')) 

3541 f(x) 

3542 / 

3543 | / 

3544 | 1 | 

3545 | - dy = C1 + | (-P(x) + Q(x)) dx 

3546 | y | 

3547 | / 

3548 / 

3549 

3550 

3551 Examples 

3552 ======== 

3553 

3554 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, Eq, pprint, log 

3555 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3556 >>> f = Function('f') 

3557 

3558 >>> pprint(dsolve(Eq(x*f(x).diff(x) + f(x), log(x)*f(x)**2), 

3559 ... f(x), hint='Bernoulli')) 

3560 1 

3561 f(x) = ------------------- 

3562 / log(x) 1\ 

3563 x*|C1 + ------ + -| 

3564 \ x x/ 

3565 

3566 References 

3567 ========== 

3568 

3569 - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernoulli_differential_equation 

3570 - M. Tenenbaum & H. Pollard, "Ordinary Differential Equations", 

3571 Dover 1963, pp. 95 

3572 

3573 # indirect doctest 

3574 

3575 """ 

3576 x = func.args[0] 

3577 f = func.func 

3578 r = match # a*diff(f(x),x) + b*f(x) + c*f(x)**n, n != 1 

3579 C1 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=1) 

3580 t = exp((1 - r[r['n']])*Integral(r[r['b']]/r[r['a']], x)) 

3581 tt = (r[r['n']] - 1)*Integral(t*r[r['c']]/r[r['a']], x) 

3582 return Eq(f(x), ((tt + C1)/t)**(1/(1 - r[r['n']]))) 

3583 

3584 

3585def ode_Riccati_special_minus2(eq, func, order, match): 

3586 r""" 

3587 The general Riccati equation has the form 

3588 

3589 .. math:: dy/dx = f(x) y^2 + g(x) y + h(x)\text{.} 

3590 

3591 While it does not have a general solution [1], the "special" form, `dy/dx 

3592 = a y^2 - b x^c`, does have solutions in many cases [2]. This routine 

3593 returns a solution for `a(dy/dx) = b y^2 + c y/x + d/x^2` that is obtained 

3594 by using a suitable change of variables to reduce it to the special form 

3595 and is valid when neither `a` nor `b` are zero and either `c` or `d` is 

3596 zero. 

3597 

3598 >>> from sympy.abc import x, y, a, b, c, d 

3599 >>> from sympy.solvers.ode import dsolve, checkodesol 

3600 >>> from sympy import pprint, Function 

3601 >>> f = Function('f') 

3602 >>> y = f(x) 

3603 >>> genform = a*y.diff(x) - (b*y**2 + c*y/x + d/x**2) 

3604 >>> sol = dsolve(genform, y) 

3605 >>> pprint(sol, wrap_line=False) 

3606 / / __________________ \\ 

3607 | __________________ | / 2 || 

3608 | / 2 | \/ 4*b*d - (a + c) *log(x)|| 

3609 -|a + c - \/ 4*b*d - (a + c) *tan|C1 + ----------------------------|| 

3610 \ \ 2*a // 

3611 f(x) = ------------------------------------------------------------------------ 

3612 2*b*x 

3613 

3614 >>> checkodesol(genform, sol, order=1)[0] 

3615 True 

3616 

3617 References 

3618 ========== 

3619 

3620 1. http://www.maplesoft.com/support/help/Maple/view.aspx?path=odeadvisor/Riccati 

3621 2. http://eqworld.ipmnet.ru/en/solutions/ode/ode0106.pdf - 

3622 http://eqworld.ipmnet.ru/en/solutions/ode/ode0123.pdf 

3623 """ 

3624 

3625 x = func.args[0] 

3626 f = func.func 

3627 r = match # a2*diff(f(x),x) + b2*f(x) + c2*f(x)/x + d2/x**2 

3628 a2, b2, c2, d2 = [r[r[s]] for s in 'a2 b2 c2 d2'.split()] 

3629 C1 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=1) 

3630 mu = sqrt(4*d2*b2 - (a2 - c2)**2) 

3631 return Eq(f(x), (a2 - c2 - mu*tan(mu/(2*a2)*log(x) + C1))/(2*b2*x)) 

3632 

3633 

3634def ode_Liouville(eq, func, order, match): 

3635 r""" 

3636 Solves 2nd order Liouville differential equations. 

3637 

3638 The general form of a Liouville ODE is 

3639 

3640 .. math:: \frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} + g(y) \left(\! 

3641 \frac{dy}{dx}\!\right)^2 + h(x) 

3642 \frac{dy}{dx}\text{.} 

3643 

3644 The general solution is: 

3645 

3646 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, Eq, pprint, diff 

3647 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3648 >>> f, g, h = map(Function, ['f', 'g', 'h']) 

3649 >>> genform = Eq(diff(f(x),x,x) + g(f(x))*diff(f(x),x)**2 + 

3650 ... h(x)*diff(f(x),x), 0) 

3651 >>> pprint(genform) 

3652 2 2 

3653 /d \ d d 

3654 g(f(x))*|--(f(x))| + h(x)*--(f(x)) + ---(f(x)) = 0 

3655 \dx / dx 2 

3656 dx 

3657 >>> pprint(dsolve(genform, f(x), hint='Liouville_Integral')) 

3658 f(x) 

3659 / / 

3660 | | 

3661 | / | / 

3662 | | | | 

3663 | - | h(x) dx | | g(y) dy 

3664 | | | | 

3665 | / | / 

3666 C1 + C2* | e dx + | e dy = 0 

3667 | | 

3668 / / 

3669 

3670 Examples 

3671 ======== 

3672 

3673 >>> from sympy import Function, dsolve, Eq, pprint 

3674 >>> from sympy.abc import x 

3675 >>> f = Function('f') 

3676 >>> pprint(dsolve(diff(f(x), x, x) + diff(f(x), x)**2/f(x) + 

3677 ... diff(f(x), x)/x, f(x), hint='Liouville')) 

3678 ________________ ________________ 

3679 [f(x) = -\/ C1 + C2*log(x) , f(x) = \/ C1 + C2*log(x) ] 

3680 

3681 References 

3682 ========== 

3683 

3684 - Goldstein and Braun, "Advanced Methods for the Solution of Differential 

3685 Equations", pp. 98 

3686 - http://www.maplesoft.com/support/help/Maple/view.aspx?path=odeadvisor/Liouville 

3687 

3688 # indirect doctest 

3689 

3690 """ 

3691 # Liouville ODE: 

3692 # f(x).diff(x, 2) + g(f(x))*(f(x).diff(x, 2))**2 + h(x)*f(x).diff(x) 

3693 # See Goldstein and Braun, "Advanced Methods for the Solution of 

3694 # Differential Equations", pg. 98, as well as 

3695 # http://www.maplesoft.com/support/help/view.aspx?path=odeadvisor/Liouville 

3696 x = func.args[0] 

3697 f = func.func 

3698 r = match # f(x).diff(x, 2) + g*f(x).diff(x)**2 + h*f(x).diff(x) 

3699 y = r['y'] 

3700 C1, C2 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=2) 

3701 int = Integral(exp(Integral(r['g'], y)), (y, None, f(x))) 

3702 sol = Eq(int + C1*Integral(exp(-Integral(r['h'], x)), x) + C2, 0) 

3703 return sol 

3704 

3705 

3706def ode_2nd_power_series_ordinary(eq, func, order, match): 

3707 r""" 

3708 Gives a power series solution to a second order homogeneous differential 

3709 equation with polynomial coefficients at an ordinary point. A homogenous 

3710 differential equation is of the form 

3711 

3712 .. math :: P(x)\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + Q(x)\frac{dy}{dx} + R(x) = 0 

3713 

3714 For simplicity it is assumed that `P(x)`, `Q(x)` and `R(x)` are polynomials, 

3715 it is sufficient that `\frac{Q(x)}{P(x)}` and `\frac{R(x)}{P(x)}` exists at 

3716 `x_{0}`. A recurrence relation is obtained by substituting `y` as `\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_{n}x^{n}`, 

3717 in the differential equation, and equating the nth term. Using this relation 

3718 various terms can be generated. 

3719 

3720 

3721 Examples 

3722 ======== 

3723 

3724 >>> from sympy import dsolve, Function, pprint 

3725 >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 

3726 >>> f = Function("f") 

3727 >>> eq = f(x).diff(x, 2) + f(x) 

3728 >>> pprint(dsolve(eq, hint='2nd_power_series_ordinary')) 

3729 / 4 2 \ / 2\ 

3730 |x x | | x | / 6\ 

3731 f(x) = C2*|-- - -- + 1| + C1*x*|1 - --| + O\x / 

3732 \24 2 / \ 6 / 

3733 

3734 

3735 References 

3736 ========== 

3737 - http://tutorial.math.lamar.edu/Classes/DE/SeriesSolutions.aspx 

3738 - George E. Simmons, "Differential Equations with Applications and 

3739 Historical Notes", p.p 176 - 184 

3740 

3741 """ 

3742 x = func.args[0] 

3743 f = func.func 

3744 C0, C1 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=2) 

3745 n = Dummy("n", integer=True) 

3746 s = Wild("s") 

3747 k = Wild("k", exclude=[x]) 

3748 x0 = match.get('x0') 

3749 terms = match.get('terms', 5) 

3750 p = match[match['a3']] 

3751 q = match[match['b3']] 

3752 r = match[match['c3']] 

3753 seriesdict = {} 

3754 recurr = Function("r") 

3755 

3756 # Generating the recurrence relation which works this way: 

3757 # for the second order term the summation begins at n = 2. The coefficients 

3758 # p is multiplied with an*(n - 1)*(n - 2)*x**n-2 and a substitution is made such that 

3759 # the exponent of x becomes n. 

3760 # For example, if p is x, then the second degree recurrence term is 

3761 # an*(n - 1)*(n - 2)*x**n-1, substituting (n - 1) as n, it transforms to 

3762 # an+1*n*(n - 1)*x**n. 

3763 # A similar process is done with the first order and zeroth order term. 

3764 

3765 coefflist = [(recurr(n), r), (n*recurr(n), q), (n*(n - 1)*recurr(n), p)] 

3766 for index, coeff in enumerate(coefflist): 

3767 if coeff[1]: 

3768 f2 = powsimp(expand((coeff[1]*(x - x0)**(n - index)).subs(x, x + x0))) 

3769 if f2.is_Add: 

3770 addargs = f2.args 

3771 else: 

3772 addargs = [f2] 

3773 for arg in addargs: 

3774 powm = arg.match(s*x**k) 

3775 term = coeff[0]*powm[s] 

3776 if not powm[k].is_Symbol: 

3777 term = term.subs(n, n - powm[k].as_independent(n)[0]) 

3778 startind = powm[k].subs(n, index) 

3779 # Seeing if the startterm can be reduced further. 

3780 # If it vanishes for n lesser than startind, it is 

3781 # equal to summation from n. 

3782 if startind: 

3783 for i in reversed(range(startind)): 

3784 if not term.subs(n, i): 

3785 seriesdict[term] = i 

3786 else: 

3787 seriesdict[term] = i + 1 

3788 break 

3789 else: 

3790 seriesdict[term] = S(0) 

3791 

3792 # Stripping of terms so that the sum starts with the same number. 

3793 teq = S(0) 

3794 suminit = seriesdict.values() 

3795 rkeys = seriesdict.keys() 

3796 req = Add(*rkeys) 

3797 if any(suminit): 

3798 maxval = max(suminit) 

3799 for term in seriesdict: 

3800 val = seriesdict[term] 

3801 if val != maxval: 

3802 for i in range(val, maxval): 

3803 teq += term.subs(n, val) 

3804 

3805 finaldict = {} 

3806 if teq: 

3807 fargs = teq.atoms(AppliedUndef) 

3808 if len(fargs) == 1: 

3809 finaldict[fargs.pop()] = 0 

3810 else: 

3811 maxf = max(fargs, key = lambda x: x.args[0]) 

3812 sol = solve(teq, maxf) 

3813 if isinstance(sol, list): 

3814 sol = sol[0] 

3815 finaldict[maxf] = sol 

3816 

3817 # Finding the recurrence relation in terms of the largest term. 

3818 fargs = req.atoms(AppliedUndef) 

3819 maxf = max(fargs, key = lambda x: x.args[0]) 

3820 minf = min(fargs, key = lambda x: x.args[0]) 

3821 if minf.args[0].is_Symbol: 

3822 startiter = 0 

3823 else: 

3824 startiter = -minf.args[0].as_independent(n)[0] 

3825 lhs = maxf 

3826 rhs = solve(req, maxf) 

3827 if isinstance(rhs, list): 

3828 rhs = rhs[0] 

3829 

3830 # Checking how many values are already present 

3831 tcounter = len([t for t in finaldict.values() if t]) 

3832 

3833 for _ in range(tcounter, terms - 3): # Assuming c0 and c1 to be arbitrary 

3834 check = rhs.subs(n, startiter) 

3835 nlhs = lhs.subs(n, startiter) 

3836 nrhs = check.subs(finaldict) 

3837 finaldict[nlhs] = nrhs 

3838 startiter += 1 

3839 

3840 # Post processing 

3841 series = C0 + C1*(x - x0) 

3842 for term in finaldict: 

3843 if finaldict[term]: 

3844 fact = term.args[0] 

3845 series += (finaldict[term].subs([(recurr(0), C0), (recurr(1), C1)])*( 

3846 x - x0)**fact) 

3847 series = collect(expand_mul(series), [C0, C1]) + Order(x**terms) 

3848 return Eq(f(x), series) 

3849 

3850 

3851 

3852def ode_2nd_power_series_regular(eq, func, order, match): 

3853 r""" 

3854 Gives a power series solution to a second order homogeneous differential 

3855 equation with polynomial coefficients at a regular point. A second order 

3856 homogenous differential equation is of the form 

3857 

3858 .. math :: P(x)\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + Q(x)\frac{dy}{dx} + R(x) = 0 

3859 

3860 A point is said to regular singular at `x0` if `x - x0\frac{Q(x)}{P(x)}` 

3861 and `(x - x0)^{2}\frac{R(x)}{P(x)}` are analytic at `x0`. For simplicity 

3862 `P(x)`, `Q(x)` and `R(x)` are assumed to be polynomials. The algorithm for 

3863 finding the power series solutions is: 

3864 

3865 1. Try expressing `(x - x0)P(x)` and `((x - x0)^{2})Q(x)` as power series 

3866 solutions about x0. Find `p0` and `q0` which are the constants of the 

3867 power series expansions. 

3868 2. Solve the indicial equation `f(m) = m(m - 1) + m*p0 + q0`, to obtain the 

3869 roots `m1` and `m2` of the indicial equation. 

3870 3. If `m1 - m2` is a non integer there exists two series solutions. If 

3871 `m1 = m2`, there exists only one solution. If `m1 - m2` is an integer, 

3872 then the existence of one solution is confirmed. The other solution may 

3873 or may not exist. 

3874 

3875 The power series solution is of the form `x^{m}\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_{n}x^{n}`. The 

3876 coefficients are determined by the following recurrence relation. 

3877 `a_{n} = -\frac{\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} q_{n-k} + (m + k)p_{n-k}}{f(m + n)}`. For the case 

3878 in which `m1 - m2` is an integer, it can be seen from the recurrence relation 

3879 that for the lower root `m`, when `n` equals the difference of both the 

3880 roots, the denominator becomes zero. So if the numerator is not equal to zero, 

3881 a second series solution exists. 

3882 

3883 

3884 Examples 

3885 ======== 

3886 

3887 >>> from sympy import dsolve, Function, pprint 

3888 >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 

3889 >>> f = Function("f") 

3890 >>> eq = x*(f(x).diff(x, 2)) + 2*(f(x).diff(x)) + x*f(x) 

3891 >>> pprint(dsolve(eq)) 

3892 / 6 4 2 \ 

3893 | x x x | 

3894 / 4 2 \ C1*|- --- + -- - -- + 1| 

3895 | x x | \ 720 24 2 / / 6\ 

3896 f(x) = C2*|--- - -- + 1| + ------------------------ + O\x / 

3897 \120 6 / x 

3898 

3899 

3900 References 

3901 ========== 

3902 - George E. Simmons, "Differential Equations with Applications and 

3903 Historical Notes", p.p 176 - 184 

3904 

3905 """ 

3906 x = func.args[0] 

3907 f = func.func 

3908 C0, C1 = get_numbered_constants(eq, num=2) 

3909 n = Dummy("n") 

3910 m = Dummy("m") # for solving the indicial equation 

3911 s = Wild("s") 

3912 k = Wild("k", exclude=[x]) 

3913 x0 = match.get('x0') 

3914 terms = match.get('terms', 5) 

3915 p = match['p'] 

3916 q = match['q'] 

3917 

3918 # Generating the indicial equation 

3919 indicial = [] 

3920 for term in [p, q]: 

3921 if not term.has(x): 

3922 indicial.append(term) 

3923 else: 

3924 term = series(term, n=1, x0=x0) 

3925 if isinstance(term, Order): 

3926 indicial.append(S(0)) 

3927 else: 

3928 for arg in term.args: 

3929 if not arg.has(x): 

3930 indicial.append(arg) 

3931 break 

3932 

3933 p0, q0 = indicial 

3934 sollist = solve(m*(m - 1) + m*p0 + q0, m) 

3935 if sollist and isinstance(sollist, list) and all( 

3936 [sol.is_real for sol in sollist]): 

3937 serdict1 = {} 

3938 serdict2 = {} 

3939 if len(sollist) == 1: 

3940 # Only one series solution exists in this case. 

3941 m1 = m2 = sollist.pop() 

3942 if terms-m1-1 <= 0: 

3943 return Eq(f(x), Order(terms)) 

3944 serdict1 = _frobenius(terms-m1-1, m1, p0, q0, p, q, x0, x, C0) 

3945 

3946 else: 

3947 m1 = sollist[0] 

3948 m2 = sollist[1] 

3949 if m1 < m2: 

3950 m1, m2 = m2, m1 

3951 # Irrespective of whether m1 - m2 is an integer or not, one 

3952 # Frobenius series solution exists. 

3953 serdict1 = _frobenius(terms-m1-1, m1, p0, q0, p, q, x0, x, C0) 

3954 if not (m1 - m2).is_integer: 

3955 # Second frobenius series solution exists. 

3956 serdict2 = _frobenius(terms-m2-1, m2, p0, q0, p, q, x0, x, C1) 

3957 else: 

3958 # Check if second frobenius series solution exists. 

3959 serdict2 = _frobenius(terms-m2-1, m2, p0, q0, p, q, x0, x, C1, check=m1) 

3960 

3961 if serdict1: 

3962 finalseries1 = C0 

3963 for key in serdict1: 

3964 power = int(key.name[1:]) 

3965 finalseries1 += serdict1[key]*(x - x0)**power 

3966 finalseries1 = (x - x0)**m1*finalseries1 

3967 finalseries2 = S(0) 

3968 if serdict2: 

3969 for key in serdict2: 

3970 power = int(key.name[1:]) 

3971 finalseries2 += serdict2[key]*(x - x0)**power 

3972 finalseries2 += C1 

3973 finalseries2 = (x - x0)**m2*finalseries2 

3974 return Eq(f(x), collect(finalseries1 + finalseries2, 

3975 [C0, C1]) + Order(x**terms)) 

3976 

3977def _frobenius(n, m, p0, q0, p, q, x0, x, c, check=None): 

3978 r""" 

3979 Returns a dict with keys as coefficients and values as their values in terms of C0 

3980 """ 

3981 n = int(n) 

3982 # In cases where m1 - m2 is not an integer 

3983 m2 = check 

3984 

3985 d = Dummy("d") 

3986 numsyms = numbered_symbols("C", start=0) 

3987 numsyms = [next(numsyms) for i in range(n + 1)] 

3988 C0 = Symbol("C0") 

3989 serlist = [] 

3990 for ser in [p, q]: 

3991 # Order term not present 

3992 if ser.is_polynomial(x) and Poly(ser, x).degree() <= n: 

3993 if x0: 

3994 ser = ser.subs(x, x + x0) 

3995 dict_ = Poly(ser, x).as_dict() 

3996 # Order term present 

3997 else: 

3998 tseries = series(ser, x=x0, n=n+1) 

3999 # Removing order
